- [x] I have starred the repository [Star_here](https://github.com/DhruvJohri/Netflix-Clone)
- [x] I agree to follow the project's [Code of Conduct](https://github.com/DhruvJohri/Netflix-Clone/blob/main/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md).

issueDTO.title: Built binaries are not stripped
issueDTO.description:
Built binaries are not stripped

## Expected Behavior
Built binaries are as small as possible to reduce docker images size.

## Current Behavior
As an example, calico-node is not stripped:
calico-node: ELF 64-bit LSB executable, x86-64, version 1 (SYSV), dynamically linked, interpreter /lib64/ld-linux-x86-64.so.2, for GNU/Linux 3.2.0, Go BuildID=Zj-dNERc1XZs22xTIG4a/6iGR1YjI3SePsudHbMMA/BM-owAa7TDzFpy2od1aW/84jlD79A8qOMoOkeJqpA, BuildID[sha1]=519824671dc019b4983ac44e98740d4c76d2c9fa, not stripped

This is the same for binaries in kube-controllers, cni and node docker images.

## Possible Solution
Use ldflags "-w -s"
comments:
The one complexity here is that we use the symbols as part of our dev process to verify the correct TLS boringcrypto symbols show up.

What we should do is keep the symbols for pre-release / development images, and then strip them when we cut a release.
@caseydavenport Please help to review [this](https://github.com/projectcalico/calico/pull/6686) solution for adding `ldflags "-w -s"` exactly during the final release.

Stripping symbols makes it very hard to debug core dumps, which don't happen often, but when they do... I feel like, if we're going to strip images, we should save off the symbols somewhere so that they can be dug out when needed.  Could also try a binary compressor instead.  I think UPX works with Go now.
This issue is stale because it is kind/enhancement or kind/bug and has been open for 180 days with no activity.

issueDTO.description:
### 📝 What needs improvement?

Description:
Currently, the README only shows 5 contributors manually listed. This issue aims to enhance the README with a dynamic contributors section that automatically updates to show all contributors to the repository. This can be done either by embedding a contributors badge powered by GitHub or by integrating a contributor listing tool.

Objectives
Replace the static contributors list in README with an automated method.

Use a badge/image from a trusted service (such as [contrib.rocks](https://contrib.rocks/)) or GitHub native contributors graph.

Alternatively, integrate the [all-contributors](https://allcontributors.org/) bot to manage and display contributors with roles.

Ensure the contributors section updates automatically as new contributors join, reducing manual maintenance.

Keep the section visually appealing and consistent with the README style.

There is no way to see that maintenance mode is starting.

only on the Maintenance page status

I come from uptime kuma
And where maintenance mode starts, all monitors that are set to maintenance mode change state to "maintenance mode"

issueDTO.title: Complete the Norwegian Bokm??l (Norsk Bokm??l) translation of Puter
issueDTO.description:
The Norwegian Bokm??l version of Puter is missing a number of translations. This task involves updating the Norwegian Bokm??l translation file to ensure that all English text is accurately translated and culturally appropriate.

### Steps to resolve
1. Scroll to the bottom of [`src/gui/src/i18n/translations/nb.js`](https://github.com/HeyPuter/puter/tree/main/src/gui/src/i18n/translations/nb.js) to find the list of missing translations
2. For each translation key that is missing the value is left as `undefined`, however the English translation is provided in the comment next to it.
3. Replace `undefined` with the Norwegian Bokm??l translation of the English text provided in the comment

### Additional notes
- Please pick up this task only if you're fluent in Norwegian Bokm??l. This is to make sure the nuances of the language are observed accurately.
- Please ensure that the translations are culturally appropriate and maintain the intended meaning of the English text
- If certain terms or phrases don't have a direct Norwegian Bokm??l equivalent, consider adding translator notes or using transliteration where appropriate
- Please be mindful of placeholders such as `%strong%` and try to appropriately place them in the translated text

### Files to be updated
- [`src/gui/src/i18n/translations/nb.js`](https://github.com/HeyPuter/puter/tree/main/src/gui/src/i18n/translations/nb.js)

Thank you for helping to improve the Norwegian Bokm??l localization of our project!

issueDTO.title: Cannot Ctrl+C to end streamlit process from CLI without an open tab (in Windows)
issueDTO.description:
### Checklist

- [X] I have searched the [existing issues](https://github.com/streamlit/streamlit/issues) for similar issues.
- [X] I added a very descriptive title to this issue.
- [X] I have provided sufficient information below to help reproduce this issue.

### Summary

This has had [a few comments in the forum](https://discuss.streamlit.io/t/cant-stop-streamlit-app-using-ctrl-c-if-the-app-has-been-closed-in-the-browser/38738) and I couldn't find mention in a current or closed issue, so documenting here. This is merely a minor inconvenience with an easy workaround for most, but noting for completeness/future searches.

In Windows, the `streamlit run` process cannot be terminated from command line with `Ctrl+C` if there are no connected tabs. The terminal itself must either be closed or a new tab open and connected to the session to register if `Ctrl+C` has been typed. The forum thread mentions a connection to tornado.

### Reproducible Code Example

```Python
# Any valid streamlit app
import streamlit as st
st.write('hi')
```


### Steps To Reproduce

1. From a terminal in Windows, `streamlit run app.py`.
2. Close any/all tabs connected to the session.
3. Ctrl+C in the terminal
(nothing happens)
4. Open a tab and connect to the session
(terminal immediately registers the previous command and correctly proceeds `Stopping...`)

### Expected Behavior

Ctrl+C should stop the process even if there are no active users

### Current Behavior

A connected tab is required to stop the process without closing the terminal

### Is this a regression?

- [ ] Yes, this used to work in a previous version.

### Debug info

- Streamlit version: 1.23.0
- Python version: 3.10.11
- Operating System: Windows 10
- Browser: Edge...or rather "none"
- Virtual environment: Conda


### Additional Information

Thematically related to #6611

### Are you willing to submit a PR?

- [ ] Yes, I am willing to submit a PR!
comments: Huh very interesting. Probably one of these bugs we never catch because nobody on the team uses Windows :D Thanks for tracking.

I'm on linux and facing similiar issues, essentially I can't ctrl-c, I have to kill the process. However I'm launching streamlit through VS Code terminal and running a torch training loop, which might be a relevant.

I have the same issue, I have to manually kill streamlit's process in task manager if I close the browser window.

Streamlit version: 1.25.0
Python version: 3.10.6
Operating System: Windows 10 (x64)
Browser: Chrome Version 115.0.5790.110 (Official Build) (64-bit)
Can confirm this happens on windows in Git Bash. Suspect related to the code never reaching some kind of yield point and being able to handle an interupt signal.

> Huh very interesting. Probably one of these bugs we never catch because nobody on the team uses Windows :D Thanks for tracking.

So how do you stop a streamlit app running under Linux?? I have this issue under both Mint and Windows.

> > Huh very interesting. Probably one of these bugs we never catch because nobody on the team uses Windows :D Thanks for tracking.
> 
> So how do you stop a streamlit app running under Linux?? I have this issue under both Mint and Windows.

i usually do `ctrl-z` to send it to the background and then `killall -9 streamlit`.

Using breakpoints and mucking around in asyncIO, I believe what is happening is that right after the Runtime transitions to `RuntimeState.NO_SESSIONS_CONNECTED`, the main event loop is hanging on this call into the `select` standard library module

https://github.com/python/cpython/blob/3.12/Lib/asyncio/base_events.py#L1913

The hanging call for me was a call to `select.select([3068], [], [], timeout=3511.89)`. The long timeout is coming from the time until the next scheduled `tornado` event. I don't know where that event gets scheduled exactly, so that's as far as I was able to get.

Is it possible that 
"if streamlit app is not connected to any html tabs"  it gets killed  immediately/or after few secs/or ...  ???
In Windows, the streamlit run process CAN be terminated from command line with Ctrl+C but you just need to hold those buttons for about 3 seconds or a little longer. That works.

> In Windows, the streamlit run process CAN be terminated from command line with Ctrl+C but you just need to hold those buttons for about 3 seconds or a little longer. That works.

this didn't work for me in the VS Code terminal :(
Edit* Ok it did, but it took about 30 seconds to kill it.

Just in case it's useful for someone.
I use Windows and Visual Studio Code, and I couldn't stop one of the streamlit apps running. I tried various methods like CTRL-C, holding CTRL-C for seconds, killing the terminal, closing the tab, and even opening a new tab, but none of them worked. The process continued to run.
Eventually, I discovered that the issue was related to a Docker process associated with that particular streamlit app. Since it was a RAG app, the Docker process was responsible for serving it. 
Once I stopped the Docker processes, the streamlit app finally stopped as well.
It is still an issue in Streamlit version 1.36.0 (Win 11 Pro 23H2, Python 3.9.19).
facing this issue on VSCODE W10, any ideas?

> facing this issue on VSCODE W10, any ideas?

I had the same issue, but after I posted my issue here, CTRL+C worked on VScode W10 terminal again.
I don't know why.
Same issue on Windows. The only way I can stop the process is to reopen the tab.

Can verify on Windows 10 with Python 3.11 (through uv) and Streamlit 1.42.0. If CTRL+C is pressed when there aren't any open tabs, then Streamlit hangs until one is opened; and if it's pressed when there are open tabs, then Streamlit crashes with the following error:

```py
Exception ignored in: <module 'threading' from 'C:\\Users\\<user>\\AppData\\Roaming\\uv\\python\\cpython-3.11.11-windows-x86_64-none\\Lib\\threading.py'>
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "C:\Users\<user>\AppData\Roaming\uv\python\cpython-3.11.11-windows-x86_64-none\Lib\threading.py", line 1590, in _shutdown
    lock.acquire()
  File "<project>\.venv\Lib\site-packages\streamlit\web\bootstrap.py", line 44, in signal_handler
    server.stop()
  File "<project>\.venv\Lib\site-packages\streamlit\web\server\server.py", line 470, in stop
    self._runtime.stop()
  File "<project>\.venv\Lib\site-packages\streamlit\runtime\runtime.py", line 337, in stop

    async_objs.eventloop.call_soon_threadsafe(stop_on_eventloop)
  File "C:\Users\<user>\AppData\Roaming\uv\python\cpython-3.11.11-windows-x86_64-none\Lib\asyncio\base_events.py", line 807, in call_soon_threadsafe
    self._check_closed()
  File "C:\Users\<user>\AppData\Roaming\uv\python\cpython-3.11.11-windows-x86_64-none\Lib\asyncio\base_events.py", line 520, in _check_closed
    raise RuntimeError('Event loop is closed')
RuntimeError: Event loop is closed
```

issueDTO.title: Add title/aria-label attribute to components that include icon buttons
issueDTO.description:
### Describe the feature in detail (code, mocks, or screenshots encouraged)

Building off of https://github.com/skeletonlabs/skeleton/issues/3588

We should aim to do a pass through the Skeleton components that implement `btn-icon` and ensure these have the appropriate props to set both the `title` and `aria-label` attribute per each. Additionally, each prop should contain a default value. The idea is these labels should describe the action in as succinct a manner possible in English. But given they are a prop so they can modified as needed for i18n purposes.

### How to Update

Setting up a new component props has a few steps:

> NOTE: remember to keep both the Svelte (.svelte) and React (.tsx) components in sync

1. Add an optional prop to the component's respective `types.ts` file
2. Add a semantic JSDoc description for each prop in `types.ts`
3. Register the new prop in the component and set a default value
4. Add the prop to the template for each icon button

We do no have a naming convention for `title` or `aria-label` attributes at present, but we should be able to keep these similar to [style prop conventions](https://www.skeleton.dev/docs/resources/contribute/components#style-prop-conventions):

- If the icon button is the root element -> no prefix needed
- If the icon button is a child element -> prefix as `fooTitle` and `fooAriaLabel`

Where `foo` represents the semantic prefix name already in use for class props, derived from Zag's spread methods, or if need be a new semantic name can be implemented.

### Attribute Presets

Per the attribute values themselves, remember they should describe the purpose of the button, not just summarize the icon, especially the `aria-label` for screen reader users.

- BAD: `title="Arrow"` -> this does not describe the purpose of the button
- GOOD: `title="Submit"` -> this is a good and semantic description of the button

### What type of pull request would this be?

Enhancement

### Provide relevant links or additional information.

The following components were reported to make use of the `btn-icon` class in .svelte/.tsx files, but I'd welcome a new dedicated audit to confirm.

> NOTE the component is the focus of this request, maintaining the playground is optional (but welcome)

```
- packages/skeleton-svelte/src/components/Toast/Toaster.svelte
- playgrounds/skeleton-svelte/src/routes/components/app-bars/+page.svelte
- playgrounds/skeleton-svelte/src/routes/components/popover/+page.svelte
- packages/skeleton-react/src/components/Toast/Toaster.tsx
- sites/themes.skeleton.dev/src/lib/components/common/Lightswitch/Lightswitch.svelte
- sites/themes.skeleton.dev/src/lib/components/generator/Controls/Controls.svelte
- playgrounds/skeleton-react/src/app/components/app-bar/page.tsx
- sites/skeleton.dev/src/components/homepage/HomeCompGrid.svelte
- sites/skeleton.dev/src/examples/guides/cookbook/stepper/Example.svelte
- sites/skeleton.dev/src/examples/components/popover/ExamplePopover.tsx
- sites/skeleton.dev/src/examples/components/popover/ExamplePopover.svelte
```

issueDTO.title: Feature Request: Improve User Experience for Stores with No Products
issueDTO.description:
Description:

Currently, when users filter by Teacher Store 1 or Teacher Store 2, the message displayed is "No products found," which may be confusing to users who are unaware that these stores don't have any products.

I suggest improving the functionality with the following changes:

    - Clarify Store Status: Instead of showing a generic "No products found" message, display a more informative message like:
    "No products available in this store at the moment."
    This would clearly indicate that the store has no products, rather than implying there???s an issue with the filtering system.

    - Product Availability Indicator: Add a feature to indicate the number of available products in each store, for example:
    "Teacher Store 1: 0 products available" or "Teacher Store 2: No products listed."
    This would help users understand if a store has any items to display.

    - Dynamic Product Filter: If possible, hide stores that have no products from the filter options to avoid showing empty selections altogether. Alternatively, leave them visible but with a note like "No products available in this store."

Why It???s Needed:

    - Clear Communication: A more informative message will prevent confusion and help users understand the status of the store.

   -  Better User Experience: This change would make the interface more intuitive by letting users know that the store is empty, instead of implying that there???s a filtering issue.

    - Transparency: It enhances the overall user experience by managing expectations about the availability of products across different stores. 

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/6853f10b-55eb-4cf2-851c-d8bd27329a4f)

issueDTO.title: Feature: endless asyncio tasks hypervisor
issueDTO.description:
Now we have some endless `asyncio.Tasks` consuming messages like [here](https://github.com/airtai/faststream/blob/main/faststream/nats/subscriber/usecase.py#L309) or in kafka/confluent/redis as well.

They have no chance to fail, but anything can sometimes things happens and users even don't see any exception about it. Thus, we should log this tasks failure and try to restart them.

* [ ] pass `broker.logger` to subscriber through setup method
* [ ] add task done callback to log an exception and restart it

It should helps users to diagnostic the problem and create Issue about accident and improve the system susteinability

issueDTO.title: Currency value formatting
issueDTO.description:
### Proposal

Hey folks,

we have found that people want to have a formatter for currencies. This is a proposal to add this to the formatting system.

 - Proposed unit: `currency-${currencyCode}`, e.g., `currency-usd` or `currency-jpy`. 
 - The currency code can then be placed neatly into the `Intl.NumberFormat` APIs ([see docs](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Intl/NumberFormat/NumberFormat#currency_2))

The implementation is very similar to the one for decimals in the end. I'd be happy to contribute this part.
comments:
ah interesting.

I guess that won't hurt to support it. I'm just wondering if it means we need to list every existing currency ?
Eventually, the answer is probably "yes". Though I would suppose that a certain subset could be sufficient for now. Even a Grafana limits itself to a subset.
Hey, @Nexucis , just gave this Issue a shot. :) Please let me know if I'm missing something in the process or any adaptions are still necessary.

issueDTO.title: Disable or change the location of log files
issueDTO.description:
**Is your feature already implemented in the latest `master`?**
Please go through the [Features README page](https://github.com/aome510/spotify-player?tab=readme-ov-file#features) to make sure your request feature hasn't been implemented.

It isn't.

**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
A clear and concise description of what the problem is.

`spotify_player` creates log and backtrace files in its cache directory each time it's started. These files pile up quickly and need to be manually removed.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
A clear and concise description of what you want to happen.

Some kind of CLI flag/config option to move and/or disable log files. I know that `--cache-folder` exists, but that moves the entire cache, including the credentials.

It would also be nice if the logs were stored in a temporary directory by default or at least cleaned up every once in a while.
comments: Should be straightforward to allow the log file format to be configurable. Currently, it has a fixed format as in https://github.com/aome510/spotify-player/blob/f408b4878004d279a4d47ae4a8e453c5c5a196c7/spotify_player/src/main.rs#L40-L43
I can work on this, but what would be more appropriate to change the path in your opinion? Command-line flag, config option, something else?
Thanks for taking this. Should be a config option in `app.toml`. See [example file](https://github.com/aome510/spotify-player/blob/master/examples/app.toml) for more references.

It would be nice to have a CLI flag/config option to move and/or disable log files, and logs could be stored in a temporary directory by default or cleaned up periodically.

issueDTO.title: Closing connections with RabbitMQ leads to warnings in the broker side
issueDTO.description:
**Describe the bug**
While advancing with some application using faststream, by coincidence I went to look to RabbitMQ logs and found lots of warnings about unexpected closed connections.

After debugging a lot locally, initially expecting that it was some bug my side, I think that I'm doing things properly (start & close). And have reduced the problem to a minimal example.

Note I'm a noob and maybe I'm missing something, but haven't been able to find anything in docs, issues, discussions about how to, properly, stop/close a connection. Also note that this problem, apparently, doesn't cause any trouble and everything seems to be working ok, just it's annoying to get all those warnings in RabbitMQ logs.

**How to reproduce**
```python
import asyncio

from faststream.rabbit import RabbitBroker

# Usage example
async def main():

    broker = RabbitBroker("amqp://user:pass@localhost:5672")

    await broker.start()
    await asyncio.sleep(3)
    await broker.close()

if __name__ == "__main__":
    asyncio.run(main())
```

And/Or steps to reproduce the behavior:

1. Run the script.

**Expected behavior**
Broker disconnects properly and no problems are logged in the Rabbit side.

**Observed behavior**
In Rabbit logs, the execution of the script leads to these logs:
```logs
2024-12-15 19:17:05.933765+00:00 [info] <0.10969.0> accepting AMQP connection 172.17.0.1:65170 -> 172.17.0.3:5672
2024-12-15 19:17:05.942399+00:00 [info] <0.10969.0> connection 172.17.0.1:65170 -> 172.17.0.3:5672: user 'user' authenticated and granted access to vhost '/'
2024-12-15 19:17:08.979577+00:00 [warning] <0.10969.0> closing AMQP connection <0.10969.0> (172.17.0.1:65170 -> 172.17.0.3:5672, vhost: '/', user: 'user', duration: '3s'):
2024-12-15 19:17:08.979577+00:00 [warning] <0.10969.0> client unexpectedly closed TCP connection
```

**Screenshots**
N/A

**Environment**
```bash
$ faststream -v
Running FastStream 0.5.33 with CPython 3.12.7 on Darwin
```

**Additional context**
RabbitMQ running locally, docker.
comments:
In the other side, using a "sister" aio-pika (9.5.3) implementation, it seems to work.

```python
import asyncio

import aio_pika
from yarl import URL


# Usage example
async def main():

    broker = aio_pika.connection.Connection(URL("amqp://user:pass@localhost:5672"))

    await broker.connect()
    await asyncio.sleep(3)
    await broker.close()

if __name__ == "__main__":
    asyncio.run(main())
```

And logs look ok:
```logs

2024-12-15 22:28:34.870976+00:00 [info] <0.11776.0> closing AMQP connection (172.17.0.1:58520 -> 172.17.0.3:5672, vhost: '/', user: 'user', duration: '3s')
```

^^^ Also, I've tried with `aio_pika.connect_robust()` all ok too.

Sorry, but I can't reproduce the problem on my side - your example works as expected with our docker-compose 🤔 

```python
import asyncio

from faststream.rabbit import RabbitBroker

async def main() -> None:
    broker = RabbitBroker()

    await broker.start()
    await asyncio.sleep(3.0)
    await broker.close()

if __name__ == "__main__":
    asyncio.run(main())
```

```log

2024-12-16 07:35:37.338315+00:00 [info] <0.712.0> closing AMQP connection <0.712.0> (192.168.65.1:30176 -> 172.19.0.5:5672, vhost: '/', user: 'guest')
```

Seems like it is an environment problem and we should take more time to dig into

Thank your for the Issue and for checking **aio-pika** case!
@Lancetnik assign

I did a little research and reproduced this behavior by breaking the FastStream [rabbit connection close method](https://github.com/airtai/faststream/blob/main/faststream/rabbit/broker/broker.py#L494). Here is code snippet:

```python
class RabbitBroker(
    # ...
):
    # ...
    async def _close(
        self,
        exc_type: Optional[Type[BaseException]] = None,
        exc_val: Optional[BaseException] = None,
        exc_tb: Optional["TracebackType"] = None,
    ) -> None:
        if self._channel is not None:
            # if not self._channel.is_closed:  # channel closing was commented out
            #     await self._channel.close()

            self._channel = None

        self.declarer = None
        self._producer = None

        if self._connection is not None:
            await self._connection.close()

        await super()._close(exc_type, exc_val, exc_tb)
    # ...
```

After these changes I started getting the same warnings from RabbitMQ:

```
2025-03-17 08:55:29 2025-03-17 05:55:29.229818+00:00 [info] <0.2382.0> accepting AMQP connection 172.23.0.1:58284 -> 172.23.0.2:5672
2025-03-17 08:55:29 2025-03-17 05:55:29.233339+00:00 [info] <0.2382.0> connection 172.23.0.1:58284 -> 172.23.0.2:5672: user 'guest' authenticated and granted access to vhost '/'
2025-03-17 08:55:32 2025-03-17 05:55:32.133272+00:00 [warning] <0.2382.0> closing AMQP connection <0.2382.0> (172.23.0.1:58284 -> 172.23.0.2:5672, vhost: '/', user: 'guest', duration: '2s'):
2025-03-17 08:55:32 2025-03-17 05:55:32.133272+00:00 [warning] <0.2382.0> client unexpectedly closed TCP connection
```

I don't know if I'm on the right track, but at least I was able to reproduce it. I guess that **aio-pika** channel is not being closed properly in some cases.

issueDTO.title: [Feature]: Change v1 Kafka storage and jaeger-ingester to use OTEL exporter/receiver
issueDTO.description:
### Requirement

We want to deprecate our own Kafka-related code, especially because it is stuck on an old & unsupported version of Sarama driver which we don't want to upgrade.

### Problem

Jaeger has two places that contain Kafka specific functionality: the v1 storage for Kafka (just the write path) and the jaeger-ingester. We cannot yet delete these components until 2026.

### Proposal

Modify Kafka storage and ingester code to use Kafka exporter/receiver from OTEL Contrib. We're already using those in Jaeger v2, and in Jaeger v1 there are precedents on using OTEL components (e.g. OTLP receiver, Zipkin receiver, etc.)

The existing Kafka integration tests will be useful to validate the functionality.
comments:
Hey @yurishkuro,

I would love to contribute to this issue and will be researching it further.
@yurishkuro is this open to work on and is this issue still relevant
Yes it is open and relevant.
@blazethunderstorm are you still working on this issue?

Hi @yurishkuro I plan to work on this, I found that Jaeger has declared `zipkin_receiver.go` and `otlp_receiver.go` with each importing the corresponding receiver from `open-telemetry-contrib`, Would we need to do the same and initialize a new `kafka_receiver.go` with importing kafka from  `open-telemetry-contrib` ?
Yes

issueDTO.title: Chatbot Integration
issueDTO.description:
###  Feature Request: Chatbot Integration in Brevity

**Goal**
Develop a smart chatbot inside the Brevity app that allows users to:
- Ask for summaries or explanations of articles
- Clarify news topics (fact-checking assistance)
- Engage in basic conversation for better news understanding

---

**Proposed Approach**
- Use **Gemini API** or **OpenAI GPT-4 API** as the backend brain
- Create a new screen or floating chatbot UI (like a chat bubble)
- If needed, add a backend Firebase Function (or prepare for future Node.js use)

---

**User Flow**
1. User taps on a chat icon in the app
2. A modal/chat screen opens
3. User types a question or news-related prompt
4. Chatbot responds using the Gemini API
5. Past conversations can optionally be stored locally or in Firestore

---

**Tech Stack**
- Dart / Flutter
- flutter_bloc for state management
- Gemini API via HTTP

---

**UI Ideas**
- Floating Action Button ??? Chat Overlay
- Chat bubble layout (like WhatsApp/Messenger)
- Show loading shimmer while bot "thinks"
- Support image/news link previews in chat

---

**Why Me?**
I'm a GSSoC contributor excited about Flutter, NLP, and building helpful AI tools. I'd love to implement the first version of this chatbot and iterate based on mentor feedback.

Please assign this issue to me.

Today, the rearrange from einops is very essential to write cleaner code within most transformers architecture and beyond. 

```python
     q = rearrange(query, 'b s (h d) -> (b s) h d', h=h)
     kv = rearrange(kv, 'b s t (h d) -> (b s) t h d', h=h)
```

However, einops comes with some caviats and need to be installed additionally to PyTorch.

I strongly believe PyTorch should provide its own optimised rearrange functional operator.

Best,
T.C

### Alternatives

Stick with einops, but I would prefer not.

### Additional context

_No response_

cc @albanD @zou3519 @Chillee @samdow @kshitij12345 @janeyx99
comments: cc @janeyx99
cc @zdevito
Pytorch provides first-class dims with similar functionality https://github.com/pytorch/pytorch/blob/master/functorch/dim/README.md#reshaping-tensors-einops
@ngimel well......... it is a bit different haha.
Also, some users on twitter asking for this: https://twitter.com/ddetone/status/1619055524196253698, https://twitter.com/francoisfleuret/status/1583704549704888320
It allows splitting and flattening dims, what's different?
Can't someone just parse the rearrange string and then convert it into a sequence of first class dims. Seems like a fun project.
Hi, could I be assigned this?

> However, einops comes with some caviats

@tchaton could you explain what you view as the caveats?
Sure. This should be prototyped as a standalone Python file that implements rearrange in terms of first class dims. Not sure what the best way to do the parser is

Should `rearrange` eventually live in `torch/functional.py` alongside e.g. einsum?

Should we also assume that `functorch`, and in particular, `functorch.dim` is available as a dependency for the `torch` dir?

> Should we also assume that functorch, and in particular, functorch.dim is available as a dependency for the torch dir?

Turns out this is not possible due to circular dependency (functorch depends on torch, so torch cannot depend on functorch). Looks like it will have to live in `functorch`.

As for the parser, I went with a very thin wrapper for simplicity.
Once we have a working implementation we can figure out where to put it; we may be able to use a lazy import to deal with the circular dependency
this issue is still open or  was  this closed  with the pull request linked above
It's in progress via linked pr

@ezyang E.g. in Mamba by @albertfgu https://github.com/state-spaces/mamba/blob/main/mamba_ssm/ops/selective_scan_interface.py#L7 are used `from einops import rearrange, repeat`. Are these now natively available in PyTorch? (as `from functorch.einops import rearrange` seems to work, but `from torch.func.einops import rearrange` does not)

@ezyang I guess should there be a roll-up issue about remaining popular einops functions used by lucid-rains and state_spaces?
cc @zou3519 on torch.funcs.einops working or not

What is `torch.func.einops`? Looking at [`torch.func` now](https://github.com/pytorch/pytorch/blob/8a209344c9900678dcf55d75783338f161341ccb/torch/func/__init__.py) and its history, I don't see that `einops` ever existed inside it.
functorch/einops exists, I feel like we just never exposed it in torch.func namespace
An addition to `torch.func` would be appreciated! ???

@zou3519 @ezyang found this the other day while using `einops.rearrange` so submitted a [PR](https://github.com/pytorch/pytorch/pull/146825) moving `functorch.einops.rearrange` to `torch.func.rearrange`. I feel it would be nice to keep the namespace like `torch.func.einops.rearrange` but not sure if it is worth it to introduce a namespace for one function...

Given appearance of `rearrange` in AGI-discovered architectures source codes, would be great to have it finally supported natively by PyTorch without needing a dependency on `einops` :)

https://gair-nlp.github.io/ASI-Arch/

issueDTO.title: Make find-and-replace matches start at the position of the caret before Ctrl+F was pressed
issueDTO.description:
Currently, if no find-and-replace query has been executed before, the first match found will be the first in all the code. The expected result mirrored in IDEs is starting at the first match after the position of the caret, which is so expected that I would classify the current behaviour as a bug.

~~As the FindAndReplace plugin is user-facing UI, not an API, changing this is not a breaking change.~~ For cautiousness' sake, this probably is a breaking change.

issueDTO.title: [Feature]: Support Anthropic API `/v1/messages` endpoint
issueDTO.description:
### 🚀 The feature, motivation and pitch

We need to add support for Anthropic API, at least for the [`/v1/messages` endpoint](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/api/messages), in order to support applications that depend on it like [Claude Code](https://github.com/anthropics/claude-code).

There are routers that implement the endpoint by wrapping the OpenAI api server from vLLM, like https://github.com/musistudio/claude-code-router and https://github.com/1rgs/claude-code-proxy

I'm not sure the difficulty, but I think it shouldn't be difficult and hopefully should be able to be added as a new endpoint within `vllm serve`

### Alternatives

_No response_

### Additional context

_No response_

### Before submitting a new issue...

- [x] Make sure you already searched for relevant issues, and asked the chatbot living at the bottom right corner of the [documentation page](https://docs.vllm.ai/en/latest/), which can answer lots of frequently asked questions.

issueDTO.title: Failed download and inbox number causes icon to clip into text
issueDTO.description:
### Checklist

- [X] I have used the search function for [**OPEN**](https://github.com/AntennaPod/AntennaPod/issues) issues to see if someone else has already submitted the same bug report.
- [X] I have **also** used the search function for [**CLOSED**](https://github.com/AntennaPod/AntennaPod/issues?q=is%3Aissue+is%3Aclosed) issues to see if the problem is already solved and just waiting to be released.
- [X] I will describe the problem with as much detail as possible.
- [X] If the bug only to occurs with a certain podcast, I will include the URL of that podcast.

### App version

3.6.0

### Android version

14

### Device model

Samsung a52s

### First occurred

Several weeks ago (only got a screenshot today but I've been it before)

### Steps to reproduce

1. Subscribe to any podcast with a reasonably long title
2. Wait until an episode appears in the inbox
3. Wait until or cause a download failure
4. See that having both a download failure icon and inbox number present causes an overlap

### Expected behaviour

There should be a bit of space between the text and icons.

### Current behaviour

Icon and title text now overlap. (Note, just a download failure *or* an inbox number causes no issues, only having *both* creates this issue)

### Logs

N/A
comments:
Example screenshot:

![Screenshot_20241226_163732_AntennaPod](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/d33ed310-7d34-4783-aba5-c5549ba036c7)
(Honestly this is a very minor visual bug on the scale of things lol)
Thank you @ImperialSquid. I reported the same in #7109 but I guess that didn't get fixed fully.
@flofriday would you be interested in taking a stab at this, given that you worked on that area before?

@keunes I guess the simplest option would be to hide the counter when there is an error. 

Would that be acceptable or do you have another vision for the fix?

I think there's two options:
* Replace the counter with the error, as you proposed
* Place the error icon left of the counter and crop the title a bit further

I would be lightly inclined towards the second, but I guess both are fine and we should go for whichever is easiest.

Cc @ByteHamster
Given that we plan to get rid of the side bar at some point, I think the easier option is the better option. (though, I think showing both would usually be nicer)
Hey there, is this issue `resolved` ?? if not , definitely would  like to take a good dip in it and try to resolve it.

Hi @Thedrogon
The issue is still open so, no, if is not 'resolved' 😉

Hi,  
I would like to work on this issue as part of my university open-source project.  
Could you please assign it to me? 😊  
Thank you!

Hi @keunes 
I'm available to work on this
Thank you

HI @mohamedsaber00 , and anyone else who is ready to jump in and help: thanks for the offer! No need to wait for our permission or 'claim' a ticket. As long as nobody wrote "I've started working on this and will submit a PR" it's safe to go ahead, in our experience.

Just have a look here: https://antennapod.org/contribute/develop/app

issueDTO.title: Rate function usage for custom animations in the docs is unclear/misleading
issueDTO.description:
## Description of bug / unexpected behavior
In the [Manim???s building blocks > Creating a custom animation](https://docs.manim.community/en/stable/tutorials/building_blocks.html#creating-a-custom-animation) section of the documentation, it is not made clear that the rate function must be explicitly called on the `alpha` parameter in `interpolate_mobject()` in order to allow for the usage of the `rate_func` parameter to work as intended.

### From that page:
> So, you just have to manipulate `self.mobject` inside `Animation` according to the `alpha` value in its `interpolate_mobject` method. Then you get all the benefits of [Animation](https://docs.manim.community/en/stable/reference/manim.animation.animation.Animation.html#manim.animation.animation.Animation) such as playing it for different run times or using different rate functions.
> [...]
> The only thing that you need to do is to define how you want it to look at every step of the animation. Manim provides you with the `alpha` value in the [interpolate_mobject()](https://docs.manim.community/en/stable/reference/manim.animation.animation.Animation.html#manim.animation.animation.Animation.interpolate_mobject) method based on frame rate of video, **_rate function,_** and run time of animation played.

### The code given:
```
from manim import *

class Count(Animation):
    def __init__(self, number: DecimalNumber, start: float, end: float, **kwargs) -> None:
        # Pass number as the mobject of the animation
        super().__init__(number,  **kwargs)
        # Set start and end
        self.start = start
        self.end = end

    def interpolate_mobject(self, alpha: float) -> None:
        # Set value of DecimalNumber according to alpha
        value = self.start + (alpha * (self.end - self.start))
        self.mobject.set_value(value)


class CountingScene(Scene):
    def construct(self):
        # Create Decimal Number and add it to scene
        number = DecimalNumber().set_color(WHITE).scale(5)
        # Add an updater to keep the DecimalNumber centered as its value changes
        number.add_updater(lambda number: number.move_to(ORIGIN))

        self.add(number)

        self.wait()

        # Play the Count Animation to count from 0 to 100 in 4 seconds
        self.play(Count(number, 0, 100), run_time=4, rate_func=linear)

        self.wait()
```

This excerpt (along with the code given after it) gives the impression that the `alpha` parameter is already adjusted for the rate function (if one is specified) and can be used directly, which is NOT the case. For example, a `rate_func` is specified as an argument to `play()` in the code above when in this case the `rate_func` parameter would have no effect whatsoever. In the current manim version, if one wishes to support different rate functions, it is required to call `self.rate_func()` on `alpha` instead of using `alpha` directly.

## Expected behavior
The documentation should be more descriptive and provide a better code snippet with the proper implementation of rate functions for custom animations.


## How to reproduce the issue
This is a page from the official documentation.
comments: Thanks for the report. Updating this particular page would be a good issue for a first contribution; might also be related to #3157
Hi, is there a reason why this issue is still open, given that PR [#4173](https://github.com/ManimCommunity/manim/pull/4173) was proposed to address it?

@pedropxoto the author of that PR seemingly self-closed without any reason I see, so I believe the issue still stands.

i've been tracking this issue to maybe pick it up myself some weekend, but I'm not planning on it, and i'm certainly not blocking others from addressing it.
This has been addressed with #4278, so I believe the issue can now be closed!

issueDTO.title: [CHORE]: Script to add relative file path header to each file and verify top level docstring
issueDTO.description:
### 🔧 Chore Summary

Create a script that automatically checks and optionally adds or fixes relative file path headers in source files. Each Python file should contain a standardized header with its relative path location for improved navigation and documentation consistency.

---

### 🧱 Area Affected

Choose the general area(s) that this chore affects:

- [x] Pre-commit hooks / linters
- [x] Formatting (black, isort, ruff, etc.)
- [x] Build system or `Makefile`
- [x] Docs or spellcheck

---

### ?????? Context / Rationale

Currently, source files lack consistent location headers, making it difficult to:
- Navigate large codebases efficiently
- Understand file organization when viewing individual files
- Maintain documentation consistency across the project
- Quickly identify file locations during code reviews

This script will standardize headers across all Python files with the format:
```python
# -*- coding: utf-8 -*-
"""Module Description.
Location: ./relative/path/to/file.py

Copyright 2025
SPDX-License-Identifier: Apache-2.0
Authors: Mihai Criveti

Module documentation...
"""
```

This reduces tech debt and improves developer experience by providing consistent file location context.

---

### 📦 Related Make Targets

Reference any relevant Makefile targets that are involved, if applicable:

- `make lint` - run ruff, mypy, flake8, etc. (should pass after header updates)
- `make pre-commit` - run pre-configured hooks (may need to handle new headers)
- `make check-headers` - new target to validate file headers using `.github/tools/fix_file_headers.py --check`
- `make fix-headers` - new target to automatically fix missing/incorrect headers using `.github/tools/fix_file_headers.py --fix-all`

---

### 📋 Acceptance Criteria

Define what "done" looks like for this task.

**Script Requirements:**
- [ ] Script implemented at `.github/tools/fix_file_headers.py`
- [ ] Script can scan all Python files in the project
- [ ] Script can detect missing or incorrect relative path headers
- [ ] Script provides interactive mode to review and approve changes
- [ ] Script provides batch mode for automated fixes
- [ ] Script preserves existing docstring content while updating location
- [ ] Script handles edge cases (files without docstrings, existing headers, etc.)

**Implementation Requirements:**
- [ ] Script follows the standardized header format shown in example
- [ ] All Python files have correct relative path headers after running
- [ ] Headers maintain consistent formatting and structure
- [ ] Copyright and license information is preserved/added consistently

**Quality Checks:**
- [ ] Linter runs cleanly (`make lint`)
- [ ] CI passes with no regressions
- [ ] No existing functionality is broken
- [ ] Script can be integrated into pre-commit hooks (optional)

**Documentation:**
- [ ] Script usage is documented with examples
- [ ] Makefile targets are added for header management
- [ ] Header format is documented for future reference

---

### 🧩 Additional Notes

**Technical Implementation Notes:**
- Script should be placed in `.github/tools/fix_file_headers.py`
- Use Python's `ast` module to safely parse and modify Python files
- Preserve original file encodings and line endings
- Handle files that already have partial headers gracefully
- Consider using `pathlib` for cross-platform path handling

**File Selection Criteria:**
- Target `.py` files in project directories
- Exclude virtual environments, build directories, and `.git`
- Focus on source code files (`mcpgateway/`, `tests/`, etc.)

**Header Template Variables:**
- `Location`: Relative path from project root (e.g., `./mcpgateway/services/gateway_service.py`)
- `Copyright`: Current year (2025)
- `Authors`: Configurable, default to "Mihai Criveti"
- `License`: Apache-2.0 (consistent with project)

**Integration Considerations:**
- Script should be idempotent (safe to run multiple times)
- Consider adding to pre-commit hooks for new files
- May need to update existing CI/CD checks that parse file headers
- Ensure script works with different Python file structures (modules, packages, scripts)

**Example Command Usage:**
```bash
# Check which files need header updates (dry-run)
python .github/tools/fix_file_headers.py --check

# Interactively review and apply changes
python .github/tools/fix_file_headers.py --interactive

# Automatically fix all files (batch mode)
python .github/tools/fix_file_headers.py --fix-all

# Fix specific directory
python .github/tools/fix_file_headers.py --fix --path mcpgateway/services/
```

issueDTO.title: [CHORE] Check SPDX headers Makefile and GitHub Actions target - ensure all files have File, Author(s) and SPDX headers
issueDTO.description:
### 🔧 Chore Summary

Create validation targets to ensure all Python source files contain proper SPDX license headers, copyright notices, and author information. This builds on the file path header script from task #317 to create comprehensive header validation for license compliance and proper attribution.

---

### 🧱 Area Affected

Choose the general area(s) that this chore affects:

- [x] GitHub Actions / CI Pipelines
- [x] Pre-commit hooks / linters
- [x] Build system or `Makefile`
- [x] SBOM, CVE scans, licenses, or security checks

---

### ?????? Context / Rationale

License compliance and proper attribution require consistent license headers across all source files. Currently, the project uses Apache-2.0 license with SPDX identifiers, but not all files may have complete headers. 

This task ensures:
- Proper SPDX license identification for automated tools
- Consistent copyright and authorship attribution
- SBOM generation and license scanning accuracy

---

### 📦 Related Make Targets

Reference any relevant Makefile targets that are involved, if applicable:

- `make lint` - run ruff, mypy, flake8, etc. (should include SPDX validation)
- `make check-headers` - existing target from #317 (extend to include SPDX checks)
- `make check-spdx` - new target to specifically validate SPDX/license headers
- `make fix-spdx` - new target to automatically add missing SPDX headers
- `make sbom` - generate CycloneDX software bill of materials (benefits from proper headers)
- `make pip-licenses` - generate markdown license inventory (benefits from proper headers)
- `make pre-commit` - run pre-configured hooks (should validate headers)

---

### 📋 Acceptance Criteria

Define what "done" looks like for this task.

**Header Validation Requirements:**
- [ ] All Python files have proper encoding declaration (`# -*- coding: utf-8 -*-`)
- [ ] All Python files have copyright notice (`Copyright 2025`)
- [ ] All Python files have SPDX license identifier (`SPDX-License-Identifier: Apache-2.0`)
- [ ] All Python files have Authors field (`Authors: Name1, Name2`)
- [ ] Script can detect missing or malformed license headers
- [ ] Script provides clear reporting of non-compliant files

**Implementation Requirements:**
- [ ] Extend `.github/tools/fix_file_headers.py` from #317 to include SPDX validation
- [ ] Create `make check-spdx` target for header validation
- [ ] Create `make fix-spdx` target for automatic header repair
- [ ] Add GitHub Actions workflow step to validate headers in CI
- [ ] Integration with existing pre-commit hooks

**Quality & Compliance:**
- [ ] All source files pass SPDX header validation
- [ ] CI pipeline fails on missing/invalid license headers
- [ ] SBOM generation includes accurate license information
- [ ] License inventory tools work correctly with proper headers
- [ ] No regressions in existing linting or formatting

**Documentation & Integration:**
- [ ] Makefile targets documented with proper help text
- [ ] GitHub Actions integration documented
- [ ] CONTRIBUTING.md updated with header requirements (if applicable)
- [ ] Developer guidelines include license header examples

---

### 🧩 Additional Notes

**Required Header Format:**
Based on existing project files, the standardized header should be:
```python
# -*- coding: utf-8 -*-
"""Module Description.
Location: ./relative/path/to/file.py

Copyright 2025
SPDX-License-Identifier: Apache-2.0
Authors: Mihai Criveti, [Additional Authors]

Module documentation...
"""
```

**Technical Implementation:**
- Extend the existing `.github/tools/fix_file_headers.py` script from task #317
- Use regex patterns to validate header components
- Support for multiple authors in comma-separated format
- Validate SPDX license identifier matches project license (Apache-2.0)
- Handle edge cases (test files, generated files, etc.)

**File Selection Criteria:**
- All `.py` files in `mcpgateway/`, `tests/`, and project root
- Exclude: `__pycache__`, `.venv`, `build/`, `dist/`, `.git/`
- Include: source files, test files, scripts, and tools
- Consider: migration files in `alembic/versions/` (may have different requirements)

**GitHub Actions Integration:**
```yaml
- name: Check SPDX License Headers
  run: |
    python .github/tools/fix_file_headers.py --check-spdx
    if [ $? -ne 0 ]; then
      echo "??? License header validation failed"
      echo "Run 'make fix-spdx' to automatically fix headers"
      exit 1
    fi
```

**Makefile Integration:**
```makefile
check-spdx:                    ## 📜 Validate SPDX license headers
	@python .github/tools/fix_file_headers.py --check-spdx

fix-spdx:                      ## 📜 Fix missing SPDX license headers  
	@python .github/tools/fix_file_headers.py --fix-spdx
```

**Error Reporting:**
- Clear output showing which files are missing headers
- Specific guidance on what header components are missing
- Summary statistics (X/Y files compliant)
- Integration with existing CI/CD failure reporting

**Dependencies:**
- Depends on task #317 (file path header script)
- Should work with existing `make sbom` and `make pip-licenses` targets
- Compatible with current pre-commit hook configuration
- No additional Python dependencies required (use standard library)

issueDTO.title: Feature: Onboarding Wizard for New Users
issueDTO.description:
## Summary

Implement a comprehensive onboarding wizard that guides new BirdNET-Go users through initial setup, educates them about AI limitations, and provides an interactive tour of the web interface. This will significantly improve the first-time user experience and reduce configuration errors.

**📝 Note: This feature proposal is open for comments and feedback from the community. Please share your thoughts on the design, suggest improvements, or indicate which aspects would be most valuable to you.**

## Background

New users currently need to manually configure BirdNET-Go through YAML files or the web interface without guided assistance. This can be overwhelming and may lead to suboptimal configurations or missed features. An onboarding wizard would:

- Guide users through essential configuration steps
- Educate about AI model limitations and appropriate use cases
- Showcase key features through an interactive tour
- Provide option to import existing BirdNET-Pi data
- Ensure users understand privacy implications and data sharing options

## Proposed Solution

### 1. Welcome Screen

On first launch, display a modal dialog with:

```
Welcome to BirdNET-Go!

BirdNET-Go is powered by the BirdNET Analyzer AI model developed by
the BirdNET Team at Cornell Lab of Ornithology and Chemnitz University
of Technology. Learn more at github.com/birdnet-team/BirdNET-Analyzer

Ready to set up your bird monitoring station?

[Get Started] [Import from BirdNET-Pi]
```

### 2. Setup Wizard (6 Steps)

#### Step 1: Location Configuration
- Interactive map widget for setting latitude/longitude
- Auto-detect location option (with permission)
- Display: "Your location helps filter species to those likely in your area"
- Show preview of common species for the selected location

#### Step 2: Audio Source
- Radio buttons for audio source selection:
  - 🎤 Microphone/Soundcard (default)
  - 📹 RTSP Stream
  - 🔊 Multiple Sources
- Audio level meter showing real-time input
- "Test Audio" button with visual feedback
- Troubleshooting link if no audio detected

#### Step 3: Language & Display
- Dropdown with 40+ language options for species names
- Time format toggle (12/24 hour)
- Timezone selection (auto-detect with override option)
- Preview of species name in selected language

#### Step 4: Detection Settings
- Preset selection with descriptions:
  ```
  ?????? Balanced (Recommended)
  Good balance of accuracy and sensitivity
  ??? Confidence threshold: 0.8
  ??? Sensitivity: 1.0
  
  🎯 High Accuracy
  Fewer false positives, may miss some birds
  ??? Confidence threshold: 0.9
  ??? Deep Detection enabled
  
  📡 High Sensitivity  
  Detects more birds, more false positives
  ??? Confidence threshold: 0.6
  ??? Sensitivity: 1.25
  ```
- "Show Advanced Settings" expandable section

#### Step 5: Privacy & Integration
- Privacy options:
  - [ ] Enable privacy filter (removes detections when human voices detected)
  - [ ] Enable dog bark filter (reduces false owl/crow detections)
- Data sharing:
  - [ ] Share detections with BirdWeather community
  - [ ] Enable anonymous telemetry to help improve BirdNET-Go
- Audio retention:
  - Export audio clips: [Yes/No]
  - Retention policy: [7 days / 30 days / Forever]

### 3. Interactive Web UI Tour

Using a JavaScript tour library (e.g., Shepherd.js), create guided tour with these stops:

1. **Dashboard Overview**
   ```
   Spotlight: Main dashboard area
   "This is your command center. Recent detections appear here
   in real-time. The summary shows your most detected species."
   ```

2. **Detection Details**
   ```
   Spotlight: Detection row
   "Click any detection to see the spectrogram, listen to audio,
   and verify or correct the identification."
   ```

3. **Live Audio Stream**
   ```
   Spotlight: Audio level indicator
   "Click here to listen to your live audio feed and check
   microphone placement."
   ```

4. **Settings Access**
   ```
   Spotlight: Settings menu
   "Fine-tune detection parameters, manage species lists,
   and configure integrations here."
   ```

5. **Species Management**
   ```
   Spotlight: Species settings
   "Add species to always include or exclude, and set
   custom thresholds for specific birds."
   ```

### 4. BirdNET-Pi Import

If user selects import option:

```
Import from BirdNET-Pi

1. Upload your BirdNET-Pi database:
   [Choose File] (Accepts: birds.db, *.sqlite)

2. Import options:
   [???] Historical detections
   [???] Species include/exclude lists
   [???] Custom species settings
   [ ] Audio recordings (if available)

3. Date range:
   From: [Date picker] To: [Date picker]

[Import] [Skip]

Progress: [??????????????????????????????] 80% - Importing detections...
```

### 5. Completion Screen

```
??? Setup Complete!

BirdNET-Go is now monitoring for bird sounds.

Quick tips:
??? First detections may take 15-30 seconds to appear
??? Check Settings ??? Range Filter to see species expected in your area
??? Enable notifications for rare bird alerts
??? Join our community forum for tips and support

[View Dashboard] [Documentation] [Run Tour Again]
```

### 6. Responsible Use Guidelines (Final Step)

After setup completion, display this important information:

```
🦜 Using BirdNET-Go Responsibly

BirdNET-Go is a powerful tool that enhances your birding experience through
AI-assisted identification. To ensure the best outcomes for both birding 
and conservation:

??? Review and verify detections before sharing observations
??? Use the confidence scores as a guide, not absolute truth
??? Cross-reference with field guides and local expertise
??? Consider seasonal patterns and habitat suitability

When contributing to citizen science:
??? Only submit observations you've personally verified
??? Include notes about visual or behavioral confirmation
??? Use AI detections as a starting point for your own observations

This approach ensures data quality for scientific research while maximizing
your learning and enjoyment of birds!

[???] I understand

[Start Monitoring]
```

## Implementation Tasks

- [ ] Create wizard component structure in web UI
- [ ] Implement state management for wizard progress
- [ ] Add API endpoint: `GET /api/v2/wizard/status`
- [ ] Add API endpoint: `POST /api/v2/wizard/complete`
- [ ] Create location picker component with map
- [ ] Implement audio source selector with level meter
- [ ] Build preset configuration templates
- [ ] Integrate JavaScript tour library
- [ ] Create tour content and styling
- [ ] Implement BirdNET-Pi import functionality
- [ ] Add database migrations for import
- [ ] Create user preference storage for wizard completion
- [ ] Add "Reset Wizard" option in settings
- [ ] Implement skip/back navigation
- [ ] Add help tooltips and contextual information
- [ ] Create responsive mobile layout
- [ ] Write user documentation
- [ ] Add integration tests

## UI/UX Considerations

- Use consistent styling with existing BirdNET-Go interface
- Ensure accessibility (ARIA labels, keyboard navigation)
- Provide clear progress indication (step 1 of 6)
- Allow users to go back and modify previous choices
- Save progress in case of interruption
- Offer "Quick Setup" vs "Custom Setup" paths
- Include contextual help and tooltips
- Support for mobile and tablet layouts

## Technical Requirements

- Frontend: Leverage existing Alpine.js/HTMX stack
- Use Tailwind CSS for consistent styling  
- Store wizard completion state in user preferences
- Graceful fallback if JavaScript disabled
- Compatible with all authentication methods
- Internationalization support for wizard text

## Success Metrics

- Reduction in support requests about initial configuration
- Increased percentage of users enabling integrations
- Faster time from installation to first detection
- Higher user retention in first week
- Positive feedback on user experience

## Future Enhancements

- Video tutorials embedded in wizard steps
- Automatic hardware optimization based on system detection
- Community-contributed location-specific tips
- Integration with hardware setup (USB audio devices)
- Suggested microphone placement based on environment

## References

- Current installation documentation: `/doc/wiki/installation.md`
- Configuration guide: `/doc/wiki/guide.md`
- Similar implementations: 
  - Home Assistant onboarding
  - Nextcloud first-run wizard
  - Gitlab initial setup

## Request for Feedback

This is a proposal for improving the new user experience in BirdNET-Go. We'd love to hear from the community:

- Which features would be most valuable to you?
- Are there additional configuration steps that should be included?
- What challenges did you face when first setting up BirdNET-Go?
- Any suggestions for the UI/UX design?

Please share your thoughts in the comments below!
comments:
Hi @tphakala,

I'd love to contribute to the onboarding wizard implementation (#887) as a frontend developer. Could you assign me to the frontend-specific portions of this issue?

I can focus on:

Wizard UI components (Alpine.js/HTMX)

# **Description:**  
We'd love to showcase the amazing people contributing to SimplifAI! Create a section (in the last of **About page** ) that displays a list of contributors.

You can either:
- Use the **GitHub API** to dynamically fetch contributors.
- Or create a **static JSON file** to list names, GitHub profiles, and optionally, profile pictures.

- Name or GitHub username
- Profile picture
- Link to GitHub profile

**Design Tips:**
- Keep it clean and responsive.
- Must match the website theme 
- Use shadcn and other supporting lib
- You can use cards, avatars, or a simple grid layout.

issueDTO.title: [Docs]: Add Developer Guide for using MCP via the CLI (curl commands, JSON-RPC)
issueDTO.description:
## Overview

This guide demonstrates how to interact with MCP (Model Context Protocol) servers using raw JSON-RPC commands via `curl` or through STDIO. This is useful for developers who want to understand the protocol at a low level or integrate MCP into custom applications.

This also serves as a sanity check to test / debug the MCP implementation provided by the gateway.

## Prerequisites

- MCP Gateway server running (typically on `http://localhost:4444`)
- Authentication token generated (if required)
- `curl` command-line tool
- `jq` for JSON formatting (optional but recommended)

## Authentication Setup

Before making any requests, generate a bearer token:

```bash
# Generate authentication token
export MCPGATEWAY_BEARER_TOKEN=$(python3 -m mcpgateway.utils.create_jwt_token -u admin --secret my-test-key)
echo ${MCPGATEWAY_BEARER_TOKEN}

# Test connectivity
curl -s -k -H "Authorization: Bearer $MCPGATEWAY_BEARER_TOKEN" http://localhost:4444/health
```

## MCP Protocol Flow

### 1. Initialize the Protocol

Every MCP session must start with an initialization handshake. **Note**: There's currently a bug with the `initialize` method via `/rpc` endpoint, so use the dedicated protocol endpoint:

```bash
# Initialize the protocol (RECOMMENDED - works around /rpc bug)
curl -X POST -H "Authorization: Bearer $MCPGATEWAY_BEARER_TOKEN" \
     -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
     -d '{
           "protocol_version":"2025-03-26",
           "capabilities":{},
           "client_info":{"name":"demo","version":"0.0.1"}
         }' \
     http://localhost:4444/protocol/initialize

# Alternative: Via /rpc (currently has a bug - see troubleshooting)
# curl -X POST -H "Authorization: Bearer $MCPGATEWAY_BEARER_TOKEN" \
#      -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
#      -d '{
#            "jsonrpc":"2.0",
#            "id":1,
#            "method":"initialize",
#            "params":{
#              "protocolVersion":"2025-03-26",
#              "capabilities":{},
#              "clientInfo":{"name":"demo","version":"0.0.1"}
#            }
#          }' \
#      http://localhost:4444/rpc
```

**Expected Response:**
```json
{
  "jsonrpc":"2.0",
  "id":1,
  "result":{
    "protocolVersion":"2025-03-26",
    "capabilities":{
      "experimental":{},
      "prompts":{"listChanged":false},
      "resources":{"subscribe":false,"listChanged":false},
      "tools":{"listChanged":false}
    },
    "serverInfo":{"name":"mcpgateway-wrapper","version":"0.2.0"}
  }
}
```

### 2. Send Initialization Notification

After successful initialization, send the initialized notification:

```bash
# Send initialized notification
curl -X POST -H "Authorization: Bearer $MCPGATEWAY_BEARER_TOKEN" \
     -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
     -d '{
           "jsonrpc":"2.0",
           "method":"notifications/initialized",
           "params":{}
         }' \
     http://localhost:4444/rpc
```

## Alternative: Server-Sent Events (SSE) Approach

For more robust communication, especially when dealing with multiple requests or when the `/rpc` endpoint has issues, you can use the SSE-based approach:

### Establishing SSE Connection

```bash
# Terminal 1: Start SSE connection (keeps connection open)
curl -N -H "Authorization: Bearer $MCPGATEWAY_BEARER_TOKEN" \
     http://localhost:4444/sse
```

This will establish a persistent connection and you'll see responses in real-time.

### Sending Messages via SSE

In a separate terminal, send JSON-RPC messages:

```bash
# Initialize
curl -X POST -H "Authorization: Bearer $MCPGATEWAY_BEARER_TOKEN" \
     -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
     -d '{
           "jsonrpc":"2.0",
           "id":1,
           "method":"initialize",
           "params":{
             "protocolVersion":"2025-03-26",
             "capabilities":{},
             "clientInfo":{"name":"demo","version":"0.0.1"}
           }
         }' \
     http://localhost:4444/message

# List tools
curl -X POST -H "Authorization: Bearer $MCPGATEWAY_BEARER_TOKEN" \
     -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
     -d '{
           "jsonrpc":"2.0",
           "id":2,
           "method":"tools/list"
         }' \
     http://localhost:4444/message

# Call a tool
curl -X POST -H "Authorization: Bearer $MCPGATEWAY_BEARER_TOKEN" \
     -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
     -d '{
           "jsonrpc":"2.0",
           "id":3,
           "method":"tools/call",
           "params":{
             "name":"get_current_time",
             "arguments":{"timezone":"Europe/Dublin"}
           }
         }' \
     http://localhost:4444/message
```

The SSE approach provides real-time responses and avoids the async/await issues present in the `/rpc` endpoint.

## Working with Tools

### List Available Tools

```bash
# List all tools
curl -X POST -H "Authorization: Bearer $MCPGATEWAY_BEARER_TOKEN" \
     -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
     -d '{
           "jsonrpc":"2.0",
           "id":2,
           "method":"tools/list"
         }' \
     http://localhost:4444/rpc
```

**Expected Response (no tools):**
```json
{
  "jsonrpc":"2.0",
  "id":2,
  "result":{"tools":[]}
}
```

**Expected Response (with tools):**
```json
{
  "jsonrpc":"2.0",
  "id":2,
  "result":{
    "tools":[
      {
        "name":"get_current_time",
        "description":"Get current time in a specific timezone",
        "inputSchema":{
          "type":"object",
          "properties":{
            "timezone":{
              "type":"string",
              "description":"IANA timezone name (e.g., 'America/New_York', 'Europe/London'). Use 'America/New_York' as local timezone if no timezone provided by the user."
            }
          },
          "required":["timezone"]
        }
      }
    ]
  }
}
```

### Call a Tool

```bash
# Call the get_current_time tool
curl -X POST -H "Authorization: Bearer $MCPGATEWAY_BEARER_TOKEN" \
     -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
     -d '{
           "jsonrpc":"2.0",
           "id":3,
           "method":"tools/call",
           "params":{
             "name":"get_current_time",
             "arguments":{"timezone":"Europe/Dublin"}
           }
         }' \
     http://localhost:4444/rpc
```

**Expected Response:**
```json
{
  "jsonrpc":"2.0",
  "id":3,
  "result":{
    "content":[
      {
        "type":"text",
        "text":"{\n  \"timezone\": \"Europe/Dublin\",\n  \"datetime\": \"2025-06-08T21:47:07+01:00\",\n  \"is_dst\": true\n}"
      }
    ],
    "isError":false
  }
}
```

## Working with Prompts

### List Available Prompts

```bash
# List all prompts
curl -X POST -H "Authorization: Bearer $MCPGATEWAY_BEARER_TOKEN" \
     -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
     -d '{
           "jsonrpc":"2.0",
           "id":4,
           "method":"prompts/list"
         }' \
     http://localhost:4444/rpc
```

### Get a Specific Prompt

```bash
# Get a prompt with arguments
curl -X POST -H "Authorization: Bearer $MCPGATEWAY_BEARER_TOKEN" \
     -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
     -d '{
           "jsonrpc":"2.0",
           "id":5,
           "method":"prompts/get",
           "params":{
             "name":"greeting",
             "arguments":{"user":"Bob"}
           }
         }' \
     http://localhost:4444/rpc
```

## Working with Resources

### List Available Resources

```bash
# List all resources
curl -X POST -H "Authorization: Bearer $MCPGATEWAY_BEARER_TOKEN" \
     -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
     -d '{
           "jsonrpc":"2.0",
           "id":6,
           "method":"resources/list"
         }' \
     http://localhost:4444/rpc
```

### Read a Resource

```bash
# Read a specific resource
curl -X POST -H "Authorization: Bearer $MCPGATEWAY_BEARER_TOKEN" \
     -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
     -d '{
           "jsonrpc":"2.0",
           "id":7,
           "method":"resources/read",
           "params":{
             "uri":"https://example.com/some.txt"
           }
         }' \
     http://localhost:4444/rpc
```

## Utility Methods

### Ping the Server

```bash
# Ping to test connectivity
curl -X POST -H "Authorization: Bearer $MCPGATEWAY_BEARER_TOKEN" \
     -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
     -d '{
           "jsonrpc":"2.0",
           "id":8,
           "method":"ping"
         }' \
     http://localhost:4444/rpc
```

**Expected Response:**
```json
{
  "jsonrpc":"2.0",
  "id":8,
  "result":{}
}
```

## Using with STDIO

For STDIO usage, you can use the MCP Gateway Wrapper:

```bash
# Set environment variables
export MCP_AUTH_TOKEN=${MCPGATEWAY_BEARER_TOKEN}
export MCP_SERVER_CATALOG_URLS=http://localhost:4444/servers/1
export MCP_TOOL_CALL_TIMEOUT=120

# Run the wrapper
python3 -m mcpgateway.wrapper
```

Then send JSON-RPC commands directly to stdin:

```json
{"jsonrpc":"2.0","id":1,"method":"initialize","params":{"protocolVersion":"2025-03-26","capabilities":{},"clientInfo":{"name":"demo","version":"0.0.1"}}}
{"jsonrpc":"2.0","method":"notifications/initialized","params":{}}
{"jsonrpc":"2.0","id":2,"method":"tools/list"}
```

## Error Handling

MCP follows JSON-RPC 2.0 error handling. Common error responses:

```json
{
  "jsonrpc":"2.0",
  "id":1,
  "error":{
    "code":-32602,
    "message":"Invalid params",
    "data":"Missing required parameter: name"
  }
}
```

## Common Error Codes

- `-32700`: Parse error
- `-32600`: Invalid Request
- `-32601`: Method not found
- `-32602`: Invalid params
- `-32603`: Internal error

## Best Practices

1. **Always initialize first**: Start every session with the initialize method
2. **Use appropriate timeouts**: Set reasonable timeouts for tool calls
3. **Handle errors gracefully**: Check for error objects in responses
4. **Use unique IDs**: Ensure each request has a unique ID for correlation
5. **Follow the protocol**: Send the initialized notification after successful initialization

## Example Complete Session

Here's a complete example session with proper formatting using the working endpoints:

```bash
#!/bin/bash

# Set up authentication
export MCPGATEWAY_BEARER_TOKEN=$(python3 -m mcpgateway.utils.create_jwt_token -u admin --secret my-test-key)

# Function to make JSON-RPC calls via /rpc (for methods other than initialize)
make_rpc_call() {
    curl -s -X POST -H "Authorization: Bearer $MCPGATEWAY_BEARER_TOKEN" \
         -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
         -d "$1" \
         http://localhost:4444/rpc | jq
}

# Function to make protocol calls (for initialize)
make_protocol_call() {
    curl -s -X POST -H "Authorization: Bearer $MCPGATEWAY_BEARER_TOKEN" \
         -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
         -d "$1" \
         http://localhost:4444/protocol/initialize | jq
}

# 1. Initialize (using protocol endpoint to avoid bug)
echo "=== Initializing ==="
make_protocol_call '{
  "protocol_version":"2025-03-26",
  "capabilities":{},
  "client_info":{"name":"demo","version":"0.0.1"}
}'

# 2. Send initialized notification (optional for HTTP-based calls)
echo "=== Sending initialized notification ==="
make_rpc_call '{
  "jsonrpc":"2.0",
  "method":"notifications/initialized",
  "params":{}
}'

# 3. List tools
echo "=== Listing tools ==="
make_rpc_call '{
  "jsonrpc":"2.0",
  "id":2,
  "method":"tools/list"
}'

# 4. Call a tool (if available)
echo "=== Calling tool ==="
make_rpc_call '{
  "jsonrpc":"2.0",
  "id":3,
  "method":"tools/call",
  "params":{
    "name":"get_current_time",
    "arguments":{"timezone":"Europe/Dublin"}
  }
}'

# 5. Ping test
echo "=== Ping test ==="
make_rpc_call '{
  "jsonrpc":"2.0",
  "id":4,
  "method":"ping"
}'
```

### Alternative: Complete SSE Session

For a more robust approach using SSE:

```bash
#!/bin/bash

# Set up authentication
export MCPGATEWAY_BEARER_TOKEN=$(python3 -m mcpgateway.utils.create_jwt_token -u admin --secret my-test-key)

echo "Starting SSE connection in background..."
# Start SSE connection in background
curl -N -H "Authorization: Bearer $MCPGATEWAY_BEARER_TOKEN" \
     http://localhost:4444/sse &
SSE_PID=$!

# Give SSE time to connect
sleep 2

# Function to send messages via SSE
send_sse_message() {
    curl -s -X POST -H "Authorization: Bearer $MCPGATEWAY_BEARER_TOKEN" \
         -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
         -d "$1" \
         http://localhost:4444/message
}

echo "=== Sending initialize message ==="
send_sse_message '{
  "jsonrpc":"2.0",
  "id":1,
  "method":"initialize",
  "params":{
    "protocolVersion":"2025-03-26",
    "capabilities":{},
    "clientInfo":{"name":"demo","version":"0.0.1"}
  }
}'

sleep 1

echo "=== Sending tools/list message ==="
send_sse_message '{
  "jsonrpc":"2.0",
  "id":2,
  "method":"tools/list"
}'

sleep 1

echo "=== Sending tool call message ==="
send_sse_message '{
  "jsonrpc":"2.0",
  "id":3,
  "method":"tools/call",
  "params":{
    "name":"get_current_time",
    "arguments":{"timezone":"Europe/Dublin"}
  }
}'

# Clean up
sleep 5
kill $SSE_PID
```

## Integration with Claude Desktop

To use this with Claude Desktop, create a configuration that points to the STDIO wrapper:

```json
{
  "mcpServers": {
    "mcpgateway-wrapper": {
      "command": "python3",
      "args": ["-m", "mcpgateway.wrapper"],
      "env": {
        "MCP_AUTH_TOKEN": "<your-token>",
        "MCP_SERVER_CATALOG_URLS": "http://localhost:4444/servers/1",
        "MCP_TOOL_CALL_TIMEOUT": "120"
      }
    }
  }
}
```

## Troubleshooting

### Common Issues

1. **Authentication errors**: Ensure your bearer token is valid and not expired
2. **Connection refused**: Check that the MCP Gateway server is running
3. **Method not found**: Verify the method name and that required tools/resources are registered
4. **Timeout errors**: Increase the timeout value for long-running tools
5. **Protocol version mismatch**: Ensure you're using a supported protocol version

### Known Issues

#### Initialize Method Error: `'coroutine' object has no attribute 'model_dump'`

If you encounter this error when calling the `initialize` method via `/rpc`:

```json
{"jsonrpc":"2.0","error":{"code":-32000,"message":"Internal error","data":"'coroutine' object has no attribute 'model_dump'"},"id":1}
```

This is a bug in the `/rpc` endpoint's initialize handler where an async function is not being properly awaited.

**Workaround 1: Use the dedicated protocol endpoint**

Instead of using `/rpc`, use the `/protocol/initialize` endpoint:

```bash
curl -X POST -H "Authorization: Bearer $MCPGATEWAY_BEARER_TOKEN" \
     -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
     -d '{
           "protocol_version":"2025-03-26",
           "capabilities":{},
           "client_info":{"name":"demo","version":"0.0.1"}
         }' \
     http://localhost:4444/protocol/initialize
```

**Workaround 2: Use Server-Sent Events (SSE)**

Use the SSE-based approach which has proper async handling:

```bash
# Terminal 1: Establish SSE connection
curl -N -H "Authorization: Bearer $MCPGATEWAY_BEARER_TOKEN" \
     http://localhost:4444/sse

# Terminal 2: Send initialization message
curl -X POST -H "Authorization: Bearer $MCPGATEWAY_BEARER_TOKEN" \
     -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
     -d '{
           "jsonrpc":"2.0",
           "id":1,
           "method":"initialize",
           "params":{
             "protocolVersion":"2025-03-26",
             "capabilities":{},
             "clientInfo":{"name":"demo","version":"0.0.1"}
           }
         }' \
     http://localhost:4444/message
```

The SSE approach allows you to maintain a persistent connection and receive responses in real-time, which is closer to how MCP is intended to work.

## Further Reading

- [[MCP Specification](https://modelcontextprotocol.io/)](https://modelcontextprotocol.io/)
- [[JSON-RPC 2.0 Specification](https://www.jsonrpc.org/specification)](https://www.jsonrpc.org/specification)
- [[MCP Gateway Documentation](https://ibm.github.io/mcp-context-forge/)](https://ibm.github.io/mcp-context-forge/)

repository.description: A Model Context Protocol (MCP) Gateway & Registry. Serves as a central management point for tools, resources, and prompts that can be accessed by MCP-compatible LLM applications. Converts REST API endpoints to MCP, composes virtual MCP servers with added security and observability, and converts between protocols (stdio, SSE, Streamable HTTP).
repository.name: mcp-context-forge

summary.main: The main goal of this guide is to provide a comprehensive overview of how to interact with MCP servers using JSON-RPC commands, including initialization, tool listing, and tool calling.
summary.validationOrRequirement: The guide requires a valid bearer token, a running MCP Gateway server, and `curl` command-line tool. It also recommends using `jq` for JSON formatting and setting reasonable timeouts for tool calls.
summary.attemptedFixes: The guide provides various examples of JSON-RPC commands to initialize the protocol, list tools, call a tool, and more. It also discusses error handling and troubleshooting common issues.
summary.otherNotes: This guide demonstrates how to interact with MCP (Model Context Protocol) servers using raw JSON-RPC commands via `curl` or through STDIO. It serves as a sanity check to test/debug the MCP implementation provided by the gateway.

issueDTO.title: [feature request] Support reading db credentials from ini file
issueDTO.description:
It'd be great to be able to pass spirit a path to an ini file instead of needing plain text credentials in a CLI, which has the downside of having those credentials visible on a host's processlist. 

Happy to lend a hand in implementation if it's something worthwhile for the project at large. Thanks!

We're interested in this feature (although we wouldn't use it ourselves due to how we automate spirit migrations).

I don't think it would be complicated to implement. We use [kong](https://github.com/alecthomas/kong) as the option parser, which can be extended to support config files.
