3772 https://github.com/cython/cython/pull/4899
4324 https://github.com/cython/cython/pull/4900

hey @da-woods @scoder could you give me some directions/tips to debug the code defined in [`Node.py`](https://github.com/cython/cython/blob/master/Cython/Compiler/Nodes.py)? I started exploring the following code, but it is difficult to understand what is going on when [`OverrideCheckNode`](https://github.com/cython/cython/blob/master/Cython/Compiler/Nodes.py#L4892) is instantiated. 

```python
def analyse_expressions(self, env): 
       self.args = env.arg_entries 
       if self.py_func.is_module_scope:  # 4646?????????4647
           first_arg = 0 
```

`OverrideCheckNode` is to do with `cpdef` functions. The most common case is that you have:

```
cdef class Something:
    cpdef some_func(self):
        pass
```

and the override check is to see if some Python code has inherited from that class and redefined `some_func`.

The less common case is for functions at module scope with `Options.lookup_module_cpdef` set. See https://cython.readthedocs.io/en/latest/src/userguide/source_files_and_compilation.html#Cython.Compiler.Options.lookup_module_cpdef.

I suspect this case may well be untested since `git grep lookup_module_cpdef` doesn't show anything in the tests.

> `OverrideCheckNode` is to do with `cpdef` functions. The most common case is that you have:
> 
> ```
> cdef class Something:
>     cpdef some_func(self):
>         pass
> ```
> 
> and the override check is to see if some Python code has inherited from that class and redefined `some_func`.
> 
> The less common case is for functions at module scope with `Options.lookup_module_cpdef` set. See https://cython.readthedocs.io/en/latest/src/userguide/source_files_and_compilation.html#Cython.Compiler.Options.lookup_module_cpdef.
> 
> I suspect this case may well be untested since `git grep lookup_module_cpdef` doesn't show anything in the tests.

Ok, thanks! I decided to write a srctree file to test it, so I defined classes A and B in different files, then I override 
the method and the module in a  `setup.py` file, but now I am trying to debug using these files without success. Is there any way to trigger just my srctree file during a debug process? Could you give me some tips?

>  Is there any way to trigger just my srctree file during a debug process? Could you give me some tips?

There's a few things you can do:

1. `python3 runtests.py name_of_your_file` just runs your test (note that `name_of_your_file` doesn't include `.srctree`)
2. `--no-capture` argument to `runtests.py` makes it much easier to use in a debugger
3. `--no-cleanup` and `--no-cleanup-sharedlibs` don't delete the files after the test finishes. That means you can change directory into `TEST_TMP` and import/run the modules yourself after the test has finished.

There's also a combined `--debug` option in `runtests.py` that enables everything that makes `pdb` usable. However:

> I decided to write a srctree file to test it, so I defined classes A and B in different files, then I override
> the method and the module in a `setup.py` file, but now I am trying to debug using these files without success.

One issue with `srctree` tests is that they run Python subprocesses as test commands. That cuts off external pdb runs. What I'd do is run it once with `--no-cleanup` and then use the resulting test directory to do your own Cython runs in it, as @da-woods suggested above. That could possibly be improved by detecting pdb and injecting a pdb command into the `setup.py` build runs of srctree tests automatically, but that might also be surprising and unwanted, so not sure it's worth implementing. Again, I'd just run the commands manually.
Hi! I would like to contribute to this, is it still open?

> Hi! I would like to contribute to this, is it still open?

Yes still plenty of untested code. Please go ahead
I'm a first time contributor and have never contributed to anything before, do you mind giving me some tips/ pointing me in the right direction to let me write test cases for one of the codes please!

The bottom one looks to be about using `break` and `continue` in `prange` loops.

The main tests for that feature are in tests/run/parallel.pyx. So look at trying to create some a loop with some observable and reliable behaviour that involves `break` and `continue`. Follow the style of the existing tests in the file - these you Python's doctest module.

You can run that individual testcase with `python3 runtests.py "run[.]parallel". The `--no-capture` argument may be useful if you want to put breakpoints in Cython's code to check if you're reaching the right lines.

There's no need to compile/install Cython - just clone the repository.

So I have a few questions: 1) I noticed that on Pycharm, I am getting red lines underneath parallel, prange, threadid as shown in the picture. The message shows that pycharm cannot find a reference for the following items. My question is, is that normal or have I screwed something up? 2) Is there a preffered setup/ method of going through the cython files. i.e: is there a .venv that I should use or is there a particular text editor that I should use/ setup in a particular way? 3) The third question I have is I am uncertain as to where to write the code that I want to be tested, do i write it in the runtests.py file and then test the file? or do i write my test case in a separate file and call that one somehow? 4) The last question is are there any resources I can refer to finish this task? I'm going through the cython documentation to learn cython but are there any other webpages/resources that I should also study to complete this task?

1. Probably normal that PyCharm can't find it. I'm not 100% sure though because I don't use PyCharm.
2. No special venv needed really. Cython doesn't have any dependencies so I just clone the git repo and edit that. 
3. Best test to add to is tests/run/parallel.pyx. No need to edit runtests.py - just use it to run the tests with the command line I suggested. 
4. I don't think there's huge amounts of relevant documentation beyond the Cython documentation. I think that if you don't already know Cython as user, then trying to contribute to it is going to be hard.
See https://github.com/cython/cython/blob/master/docs/CONTRIBUTING.rst and https://github.com/cython/cython/wiki/HackerGuide#the-test-suite for some general help with getting started.

The original bug report template was missing a helpful note at the top to remind users to search for existing issues before creating a new one. This can reduce duplicates and make issue tracking easier.
name: 🐛 Bug Report
description: Report a bug or unexpected behavior in the project
title: "[Bug] "
labels: [bug]
assignees: []

body:
  - type: markdown
    attributes:
      value: |
        **Note**: Please make sure you've searched existing issues before submitting.

  - type: input
    id: what-happened
    attributes:
      label: What happened?
      description: A clear and concise description of what the bug is.
      placeholder: Describe the issue...
    validations:
      required: true

  - type: textarea
    id: steps-to-reproduce
    attributes:
      label: Steps to Reproduce
      description: Describe how to reproduce the issue step-by-step.
      placeholder: |
        1. Go to '...'
        2. Click on '...'
        3. Scroll down to '...'
        4. See error
    validations:
      required: true

  - type: textarea
    id: expected-behavior
    attributes:
      label: Expected Behavior
      description: What you expected to happen instead.
    validations:
      required: false

  - type: input
    id: environment
    attributes:
      label: Environment
      description: OS, Python version, browser, or other details.
      placeholder: e.g. Windows 11, Python 3.11, Chrome

issueDTO.title: [proposal] Expose Reservation CR Metrics for Resource Utilization Monitoring
issueDTO.description:
<!-- Please only use this template for submitting proposal -->

**What is your proposal**:

  Expose Reservation CR Metrics for Resource Utilization Monitoring

**Why is this needed**:

  On GPU-enabled nodes, CPU and memory resources are frequently ??????underutilized??????. To optimize resource efficiency, CPU-intensive tasks are scheduled on these nodes. However, this leads to ??????GPU task scheduling failures?????? when CPU tasks monopolize excessive CPU/memory resources, starving GPU workloads of necessary compute capacity. Implement a ??????persistent reservation mechanism?????? that:
1. Permanently reserves a dedicated portion of CPU/memory resources ??????exclusively for GPU tasks?????? on each GPU node.
2. Exposes granular metrics for each reservation to monitor: Resource allocation status (e.g., allocated CPU cores, memory)

**Is there a suggested solution, if so, please add it**:

  Expose related resource usage through metrics, similar to the elasticquota plugin.
comments: Reservation cr is an object provided to resources that need Reservation. I am not sure why we need to care about its usage? 🤔

@qinfustu CMIIW, I suppose you want to record the metrics about the reservations' requests to calculate the resource allocation rate of the cluster. It is a good point! And we can add a [GCGaugeVec](https://github.com/koordinator-sh/koordinator/blob/main/pkg/util/metrics/expire_metric.go#L43) named `scheduler_reservation_requests` for it. Please feel free to contribute!

@saintube Correct. The first task is to calculate the cluster resource allocation rate. Additionally, as described in my earlier scenario, reservations are persistently reserving node resources for GPU pods. We need to calculate the allocated value of these reservations to evaluate whether the request configuration is properly set. Add scheduler_reservation_spec and scheduler_reservation_status metrics to expose request, allocatable, and allocated resource data.
Hello I would like to work on this issue, please assign it to me!
@zk2k2 Excellent! I've already developed a version that's in internal use. I'll reference your implementation for future iterations.

> Hello I would like to work on this issue, please assign it to me!

Welcome!
/assign @zk2k2

@zk2k2 Are you still working on this issue? 😄 
If not I want to take this. I understand the context of this requirement.
@googs1025 No sadly I got too busy, it's all yours, good luck!

After some thought, it seems that we should record the indicators in this way, but I am not sure if it is too complicated? 🤔 

```yaml
koordinator_reservation_resource_utilization{namespace="default", reservation_name="reservation-1", resource="cpu"} 0.75
koordinator_reservation_resource_utilization{namespace="default", reservation_name="reservation-1", resource="memory"} 0.5
koordinator_reservation_resource_utilization{namespace="default", reservation_name="reservation-1", resource="nvidia.com/gpu"} 0.5

```
/assign

issueDTO.title: [proposal] runtime hook should support initContainers
issueDTO.description:
<!-- Please only use this template for submitting proposal -->

**What is your proposal**:

The runtime hook CPUSetAllocator in the koordlet is responsible for binding CPUs for pods following the scheduling result. However, it ignores the init containers due to historical performance and timeliness issues.

After [the native sidecar container feature](https://kubernetes.io/blog/2023/08/25/native-sidecar-containers/) is introduced to Kubernetes 1.28, init containers of a pod can be long-running if they set restartPolicy as `Always`.

To properly manage the resources of the sidecar containers, the runtime hooks should reconsider the init containers.

**Why is this needed**:


**Is there a suggested solution, if so, please add it**:

summary.otherNotes: The feature aims to analyze a user's skills or resume and map them to relevant career paths using AI, based on current job market trends. It uses Gemini API to parse skills, match with trending tech careers, and return top 3-5 suitable roles. The frontend implementation includes a new route, components for resume upload or skill entry form, output card for suggested roles, and skill match percentage. The contributor notes mention not to modify existing chatbot or resume builder logic, add this feature in a new route with proper component isolation, make UI compatible with light & dark themes, and prepare for future backend integration.

issueDTO.title: Add markdown as copy format
issueDTO.description:
## Background

### Maintable

The current context menu of a main table entry contains two copy preview options:

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/1738a19f-5d4d-4eca-8641-4ffa6ab53dfb)

### Preview Area

The context menu of the preview only offers copying HTML:

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/860d698f-9205-4c63-b8a8-e2dc7ab9bc86)

## Task

1. Add "Copy citation (Markdown) as context menu entry to main table context menu
2. Add "Copy citation (Markdown) as context menu entry to preview panel
3. Add `CSL.setConvertLinks()` to CSL configuration (stated at https://github.com/michel-kraemer/citeproc-java/issues/252#issuecomment-2511285869)

## Note

- This task is related to https://github.com/JabRef/jabref/issues/12551. It can be done before or after the other task. If done in parallel, there will be some merge conflicts (but propbaly not too large)
- This is a follow-up to https://github.com/JabRef/jabref/pull/12220

issueDTO.title: 🐛 Bug Report: `appwrite function get-execution` crashes with TypeError
issueDTO.description:
### 👟 Reproduction steps

When I created a cloud function on Node 22, set it to run on update for database documents and run `appwrite functions get-execution` to get logs, the output ends with `TypeError: Cannot convert undefined or null to object`.

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/0ee42a61-b711-4960-a43c-e9b5acfff6aa)

The error comes from this [specific line](https://github.com/appwrite/sdk-for-cli/blob/7773439c6ea2691ec93e147b15a0f339b99840a5/lib/parser.js#L38), a check for whether the "object" is null seems to be missing.

### 👍 Expected behavior

It should either log the scheduledAt data or an empty object or null

### 👎 Actual Behavior

it actually fails with a type error

### 🎲 Appwrite version

Appwrite Cloud

### 💻 Operating system

MacOS

### 🧱 Your Environment

No customised environment, using the appwrite cloud software and the Appwrite SDK

### 👀 Have you spent some time to check if this issue has been raised before?

- [x] I checked and didn't find similar issue

### 🏢 Have you read the Code of Conduct?

- [x] I have read the [Code of Conduct](https://github.com/appwrite/.github/blob/main/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md)

issueDTO.title: [proposal] Add E2E tests for koordlet
issueDTO.description:
<!-- Please only use this template for submitting proposal -->

## Background

**What is your proposal**:

Currently, the end-to-end test for the koordlet is missing. Though the basic metrics reporting and batch overcommitment are tested in the slo-controller's E2E, we expect to check the QoS strategies provided by the koordlet like BECPUSuppress, BEMemoryEvict, BECPUEvict, CPUBurst, CPU QoS/Memory QoS, and so on.

**Why is this needed**:


**Is there a suggested solution, if so, please add it**:

Since #1573 and #1688, the E2E workflows are enabled on the CI pipeline of GitHub Actions. We can easily add new E2E tests in `test/e2e` and `.github/workflows/e2e-k8s-xxx.yaml`.

## PRs ARE WELCOME

Since the environmental problems and various functionalities sometimes confuse new contributors and enthusiasts, it can be a good opportunity to check and write E2E cases especially when you are deploying the Koordinator in your local cluster for the first time.

## Roadmap

- Deployment Check
  - Deploy koordlet in different versions of Kubernetes clusters.
    - [ ] Kubernetes 1.18 (minimum required version)
    - [x] Kubernetes 1.22 #1573
    - [x] Kubernetes 1.24 #1573
    - [x] Kubernetes 1.26
    - [x] Kubernetes 1.28
    - [x] Kubernetes latest (KinD supported)
  - Deploy koordlet in different [resource management modes](https://koordinator.sh/docs/designs/nri-mode-resource-management#alternatives).
    - [x] Deploy koordlet as **standalone** mode. #1705
    - [ ] Deploy koordlet as **nri** mode.
    - [ ] Deploy koordlet as **runtime-proxy** mode, also deploy koord-runtime-proxy.
- Function Test
  - Node metrics collection, estimation and reporting
    - [x] Node Metric Reporting: verified in the "BatchResource" case. #1688
    - [x] NodeTopologyReport: verified in the "CPUNormalization" case. #1688
    - [ ] Node Prediction: ProdReclaimable
    - [ ] CPICollector & Libpfm4
    - [ ] PSICollector
    - [ ] Accelerator
    - [ ] ColdPageCollector
    - [ ] HugePageReport
  - Runtime hook
    - [ ] BatchResource
    - [ ] CPUSetAllocator & BECPUManager
    - [ ] GroupIdentity
    - [ ] CPUNormalization
    - [ ] CoreSched
    - [ ] GPUEnvInject
  - QoS Plugin
    - [ ] RdtReconcile
    - [ ] BECPUSuppress
    - [ ] BEMemoryEvict
    - [ ] CPUBurst
    - [ ] MemoryQoS (CgroupReconcile)
    - [ ] BlkioReconcile
    - [ ] SystemConfig
- Others
  - [ ] Performance & Scalability
  - [ ] Robustness

issueDTO.title: Support autoscaling of vineyard cluster on the kubernetes.
issueDTO.description:
Describe your problem
---------------------

Although we have the spill/checkpoint mechanism to handle the scenarios out of memory locally, the existing mechanism is not suitable on the kubernetes, so we hope to introduce the [Horizontal Pod Autoscaling](https://kubernetes.io/docs/tasks/run-application/horizontal-pod-autoscale/) mechanism to implement the autoscaling of the vineyard cluster on the kubernetes. 
The issue mainly includes the following tasks.

- [ ] Find a proper watermark of memory usage to scale out or scale in.
- [ ] Expose the metric of memory usage to the vineyard operator.
- [ ] Create a HorizontalPodAutoscaler for controlling the scaling of the vineyard cluster.
comments: Is the issue still relevant?
Hi @Rajdeep1311, do you have any interests on this?
Yeah I would like to take a look @dashanji
@Rajdeep1311 It's nice to hear that, already assigned to you. If you have encountered any questions, please feel free to open here.
Sure @dashanji
I will be needing some help sir @dashanji

Hi @Rajdeep1311, are there any questions you have encountered? 
I think you could try to deploy a vineyard cluster on Kubernetes and create an HPA related to it.

@dashanji Yes, sir, I have done that. So what I have done is, deployed the vineyard cluster using helm charts, and I have noticed that the deployment named (vineyard-controller-manager) has some resource limits and requests already configured. I have configured an HPA related to the memory usage. But what should be the limit for scaling up the pods, sir?
@dashanji, Also, I have a few more questions, if you don't mind me asking, sir?

> But what should be the limit for scaling up the pods, sir?

The scaling indicator should be the amount of memory currently used by vineyard. First, you may need to expose Vineyard's memory usage to Kubernetes.


> Also, I have a few more questions, if you don't mind me asking, sir?

Sure, please feel free to ask.

@dashanji yes sir, I get that...but I have a few questions

1. What should be the min and max number of replicas of the pods?

2. There are 2 different containers, should I use their memory usages separately? Also both the containers have the same limit and request for memory i.e. 500Mi and 300Mi...but as I use the metrics server to get the memory usage by the pods it is barely 50Mi

3. What should be the threshold...as of now I have configured that if the memory usage by the deployment is 80% it should scale up?

issueDTO.title: <shift>-<enter> should do an enter but keep user control
issueDTO.description:
**Describe the bug**
Sometimes I want to tell gemini cli: 
"""
Look at this output, this is clearly wrong:

  - gic_migration_2024_06_25: ??? Assertion passed: Command succeeded.
  - sakura_repo_exists: ??? Path exists: /Users/ricc/git/sakura
"""

Where the first part (lines 1/2) im typing and the second part (3/4) is the output of some commands i cut pasted.

However, as soon as I press the first eNTER i lose control and gemini cli gets it. We need to have some mechanism to introduce an <ENTER> without ceding focus to the LLM and still be in tyiuping mode.

I suppose SHIFT ENTER is the most natural, but happy to consider others too (or maybe one exists and Im not aware of it)
comments:
I'd support this, and it would be a good first issue for someone interested in contributing.

If no one takes it though then I will.

Heads up, we do support shift-enter on mac if you follow the same steps that Claude asks you to follow to configure your terminal to support it. https://b.corp.google.com/issues/424007249 has more details.
Related: #1699
,take

Just to add, I personally use the Warp Terminal on Mac. By default, Warp allows you to add a new-line using either of the following:

* ??? + ??? Enter
* ??? + ??? Enter

But once you are running Gemini, it doesn't work with either approach.
Thamks for the info on warp. We would really appreciate a pull request to make both of them work  when Gemini Cli is running in warp.

hey @maisyk as per my knowledge warp isnt a terminal on its own, it uses a custom Rust-based UI framework and handles input at the application layer, not via the OS TTY driver

Warp collects keystrokes in its own internal editor, only sending the buffer to the shell on Enter or whatever you configure

so when we use gemini on warp, it is no different than using a gemini on a normal terminal, i hope this helps us understand this issue better

hey @jacob314 i have been trying to create pull requests, but i have been getting this cla error, i tried going through the the entire process mentioned in the initial readme file. i mightve made some error surely but im not able to fix it or anything i dont even know what really is happening

@jacob314 @palladius

That still works in claude code though (I'm working out of Windsurf editor atm)
hey @leonk-sportsbet wdym "stopped working" was it working on the older versions ?

Oh and it occurs to me that it might be more complicated for me.. I'm using PowerShell, but I'm using Gemini CLI in Sandbox mode (Docker), so Gemini CLI is running on a Linux container, but is running within PowerShell (/Windows Terminal).
We need a fix for this

We have updated the help text to support the different platforms. `https://github.com/google-gemini/gemini-cli/blob/7ffe8038efaa5bf263a2a933819bcd4badd37dc2/packages/cli/src/ui/components/Help.tsx#L112`

@scottdensmore this request was to support Shift+Enter, but that change just documents using Ctrl+Enter.

Is it possible (even if it requires changes in the terminal) to support Shift+Enter on Windows? For many other apps, Shift+Enter does newlines and Ctrl+Enter often submits. It's quite confusing to have the opposite behaviour.
I also think Shift-Enter would be more natural on Linux too, Alt is used in many terminal emulators for different purposes (I use if for making a new pane for example)
Assigned this to myself as https://github.com/deepankarsharma is working on it but I'm not able to assign it to him.
Is `\` `enter` still supposed to move to a new line in gemini-cli?
Hey! Any news here? Do we have temporary solution?
workaround: `ctrl` + `j`

Here are some known recipes for making multiline pastes and Shift-Enter work correctly with Gemini CLI and popular terminal environments: ## iTerm2 First, turn on the "Terminal may enable paste bracketing" option in the profile. See the screenshot below. This fixed multiline pastes. Before this any newline in the pasted text would trigger entering the prompt. I think this option should actually be enabled by default, but it was disabled for me, so I had to turn it back. Second, create a key mapping from Shift-Enter to "\n", see the screenshot below. This allows using Shift-Enter to enter new lines in the prompt. This mapping is what Claude Code creates automatically, but with Gemini CLI you need to create it manually. ## VS Code Press Cmd+Shift+P (or Ctrl-Shift-P on Linux / Windows) and invoke "Preferences: Open Keyboard Shorcuts (JSON)" setting. In the editor that opens add the following mapping: ```json [ { "key": "shift+enter", "when": "terminalFocus" "command": "workbench.action.terminal.sendSequence", "args": { "text": "\u001b\u000d" } } ] ``` This will enable Shift-Enter to work.
@aalexand awesome! But the terminal in VS Code still doesn't work.

hey @aalexand this seems like a pretty local fix it only works in iTerm2, and only if you set it up manually. most terminals don???t actually send shift+enter as a separate input, so even if gemini-cli wanted to support it, there???s nothing to detect unless the terminal is set up to do it.

also
"This mapping is what Claude Code creates automatically,"
do you (or anyone else) have an idea how claude code handles shift+enter or how does it set up this shift+enter thingy for you? does it use some trick or a different input system? are there any other opensource-cli's that we can maybe analyse to get some more idea of how it works ?

> hey [@aalexand](https://github.com/aalexand) this seems like a pretty local fix it only works in iTerm2, and only if you set it up manually. most terminals don???t actually send shift+enter as a separate input, so even if gemini-cli wanted to support it, there???s nothing to detect unless the terminal is set up to do it.
> 
> also "This mapping is what Claude Code creates automatically," do you (or anyone else) have an idea how claude code handles shift+enter or how does it set up this shift+enter thingy for you? does it use some trick or a different input system? are there any other opensource-cli's that we can maybe analyse to get some more idea of how it works ?

What I saw is that with iTerm2 at least, Claude Code created that exact key mapping as well.

> also
> "This mapping is what Claude Code creates automatically,"
> do you (or anyone else) have an idea how claude code handles shift+enter or how does it set up this shift+enter thingy for you? does it use some trick or a different input system? are there any other opensource-cli's that we can maybe analyse to get some more idea of how it works ?

Claude Code creates this mapping in the iTerm2 configuration as part of the `/terminal-setup` command that it also runs automatically on first use. This is mentioned [here](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/terminal-config).

repository.description: An open-source AI agent that brings the power of Gemini directly into your terminal.
repository.name: gemini-cli

summary.main: The main goal of the issue is to implement a mechanism for introducing an Enter key without losing control of the input, which is currently not possible due to the default macOS Terminal stripping the Shift modifier information from the Enter key and arrow keys.
summary.validationOrRequirement: The issue requires a mechanism to introduce an Enter key without ceding focus to the LLM and still be in typing mode. Shift-Enter is the most natural solution, but other alternatives may be considered.
summary.attemptedFixes: The author attempted a code-only fix by teaching the application to listen for a different key combination, Shift+Down, which often sends a unique sequence on other terminals. However, this proof-of-concept did not work, and it was discovered that the terminal sent the standard escape code for a plain Cursor Down key.
summary.otherNotes: Shift-Enter should do an enter but keep user control, as described in the bug. The issue is that the default macOS Terminal strips the Shift modifier information from both the Enter key and the arrow keys, making a code-only fix for a Shift+Key newline combination unfeasible on this specific platform. The desired path forward is to find a solution for this issue.

issueDTO.title: [Docs]:  Improve README with Website Screenshot to Showcase Features
issueDTO.description:
### 📝 What needs improvement?

Enhance the README file by adding clear and visually engaging screenshots of the website interface and key features. This will help users and contributors quickly understand what the project offers and how it works, improving onboarding and project visibility.

Details:

Capture high-quality screenshots of the main website pages demonstrating important features like flowchart creation, diagram export, AI resume tools, etc.

Add these screenshots to the README using Markdown image syntax with relative paths or hosted URLs. Example syntax:

text
![Feature Screenshot](images/feature1.png)
Organize screenshots alongside concise explanatory text describing each feature.

Optionally include animated GIFs or short videos if available, to show interactive usage.

Ensure images are optimized for web with reasonable file size and resolution.

If screenshots are stored in the repo, create a dedicated folder (e.g., /images or /docs/screenshots) for better management.

Benefits:

Makes the README more attractive and informative at a glance.

Helps new users understand the website functionality without needing to visit the site or run it locally immediately.

Encourages more contributions and usage by clearly showcasing the visual and interactive strengths of the project.


For reference, here is the basic Markdown syntax to add an image from a repo folder:

text
![Alt text describing the image](relative/path/to/screenshot.png)
Or from a URL:

text
![Alt text](https://link.to/screenshot.png)

### 💡 Suggested Fix

_No response_

### 📎 Additional Information

_No response_

- [x] I have searched existing issues and documentation to ensure this hasn't already been addressed.

issueDTO.title: Documentation for example force plot needs updating
issueDTO.description:
Hi, I noticed that the example code is a bit out of date with newer releases of the shap package. It's a small thing but I couldn't figure out what was going on until I dug into the source code and realized is should just try shap_values.values. I'm pasting a picture of the slight code changes below:

# Loading the basic example data
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/14253227/111574716-3fb45c80-876a-11eb-94b6-3839959c6d24.png)

# Trying the tutorial version of force plots
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/14253227/111574792-68d4ed00-876a-11eb-92f7-426d392fd9e8.png)

# Adding the expected value which is required in shap 0.39.0
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/14253227/111574910-95890480-876a-11eb-8846-8bb17e4e0223.png)

# Since it still didn't work I tweaked around with the code and shap_values.values works
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/14253227/111574981-bcdfd180-876a-11eb-9275-ba9642d092cb.png)

I guess I got it to work but it seems to me that there is a bug in the visualize() function. For some reason it's not detecting that the shap_values passed is in fact an Explain object and so it sends the user the message: AssertionError: visualize() can only display Explanation objects (or arrays of them)!
comments: This fix only works for tree ensemble models (XGBoost/LightGBM/CatBoost/scikit-learn/pyspark models) as those produce `shap_values` that have a `values` element. This doesn't work for deep learning or model agnostic shap, which just output a list of shap values.

This issue has been inactive for two years, so it's been automatically marked as 'stale'. 

 We value your input! If this issue is still relevant, please leave a comment below. This will remove the 'stale' label and keep it open. 

 If there's no activity in the next 90 days the issue will be closed.

issueDTO.title: Fix error-prone usage of `ColorBgra` with straight vs premultiplied alpha
issueDTO.description:
Related to #1543, it's very easy to introduce transparency-related bugs with `ColorBgra` from mixing up straight alpha vs premultiplied alpha.

Since this is our pixel type for directly manipulating a `Cairo.ImageSurface`'s data (which is always premultiplied alpha), I think `ColorBgra` also should only ever store premultiplied alpha

- [ ] Remove usage of `ColorBgra.Blend()`, which expects straight alpha (see #1546 
- [ ] Replace `ColorBgra.NewAlpha()` with a version that expects the color to be in premultiplied alpha
- [ ] `ToPremultipliedAlpha()` and `ToStraightAlpha()` should be made private if possible. The conversion functions to and from `Cairo.Color` (which is in straight alpha) should do the alpha conversion as well since it's very easy to accidentally miss this.
- [x] Verify the correctness of `ColorDifference()` which seems to multiply by alpha (done in #1639)
- [x] The `HexString`-related methods could likely be merged into `Cairo.Color`  (done in #1626)

repository.description: Simple GTK Paint Program
repository.name: Pinta

summary.main: Fix error-prone usage of `ColorBgra` with straight vs premultiplied alpha
summary.validationOrRequirement: Only store premultiplied alpha in `ColorBgra`, Convert `ColorBgra.NewAlpha()` to expect premultiplied alpha, Convert `Cairo.Color` conversion functions to premultiplied alpha
summary.attemptedFixes: Remove usage of `ColorBgra.Blend()`, Replace `ColorBgra.NewAlpha()` with a version that expects the color to be in premultiplied alpha, Make `ToPremultipliedAlpha()` and `ToStraightAlpha()` private, Verify the correctness of `ColorDifference()`

issueDTO.title: Implement mgp object serialization
issueDTO.description: It would be useful if all objects from [`mgp`](https://github.com/memgraph/memgraph/blob/master/include/mgp.py) are `JSON` serializable, that is, that there is some kind of method that returns Python `Dict` of `mgp` objects. For example, when I'm writing a [query module for database export](https://github.com/memgraph/mage/pull/100), I'm actually creating a `JSON` file with a list of nodes and relationships. Therefore, I have to reach every label, property, etc. of each `Vertex` and `Edge`. I would like to be able to just add properties as a list to my properties key, but then `mgp.Vertex.properties` is not `JSON` serializable. I solved this by going through all properties and creating new dictionary, but I think that the right place for this code would be inside mgp and not query module. Since we're going to create new utility modules similar to the export one, this feature may come in handy.
comments:
Since we added the support for functions, there are more places where this type of functionality can fit:
* [Mage](https://github.com/memgraph/mage) because if this is implemented as a function, it could be used as a part of any expression
* As a ["built-in" Memgraph function](https://github.com/memgraph/memgraph/blob/master/src/query/interpret/awesome_memgraph_functions.hpp)

issueDTO.title: Use constraints as indices if possible
comments: @Josipmrden, did we implement this? I think so. Can you link the PRs implementing this and close this issue?

Memgraph's current architecture creates a skip list for each uniqueness constraint and index.

Typically, you would have the index on uniqueness constraint. This presents a 2x memory reduction on the total number of nodes:

10 milion nodes with application ID = 1GB (approximately)
10 milion nodes with index on application ID = 2 GB (approximately)
10 milion nodes with a constraint on the application ID = 3GB (approximately)
Scaling this by a factor of 10:
100M nodes = 10GB
100M nodes + index = 20GB
100M nodes + index + constraint = 30GB
Scaling this  by a factor of 10
1B = 100GB
1B nodes + index = 200GB
1B  nodes + index + constraint = 300GB

Previous attempts: https://github.com/memgraph/memgraph/pull/1356

issueDTO.title: Add IS NOT NULL to query builder
issueDTO.description:
Below should work:
```
Python: `match().node(variable='n').to().node(variable='m').where(item='n.name', operator=Operator.IS_NOT_NULL).return_()`
Cypher: `MATCH (n)-[]->(m) WHERE n.name IS NOT NULL RETURN *;`
```

Currently, there is no operator IS_NOT_NULL in Operator Enum and where() necessarily requires three arguments (literal or expression as third), while in this case there would be 2 args)
comments: I also have a need for this - currently unable to do the query I want in the query builder without it

issueDTO.title: Fix min int value throws error
issueDTO.description:
**Memgraph version**
2.3.1

**Environment**
Windows, Docker, Bolt, PHP Bolt library

**Describe the bug**
When I run query with min int value I get error:
Integer literal exceeds 64 bits. (Memgraph.ClientError.MemgraphError.MemgraphError)

Min int value on x64 is -9223372036854775808

**To Reproduce**
1. Run query `RETURN $i` over bolt protocol with min int value as parameter.

**Expected behavior**
I expect to get min int value instead of error.
comments:
I've tried to recreate the issue with `pymgclient` -> https://youtu.be/tiSP255Ukx0?t=3971
The code is:
```
import mgclient
conn = mgclient.connect(host='127.0.0.1', port=7687)
cursor = conn.cursor()
cursor.execute("RETURN $i;", {'i': -9223372036854775808})
row = cursor.fetchone()
print(row)
```
Python client seems to return a valid result.

@stefanak-michal could you please double-check that the issue is not somewhere inside the PHP Bolt library?
I have put this task into the backlog.

issueDTO.title: Implement a COLLECT subquery that correctly handles null values
issueDTO.description:
Aggregation function `collect(t.id, p.id);` automatically ignores null values and doesn't add them to the list; the returned collection does not contain any nulls. 

**Feature request:** Implement COLLECT subquery which will not remove null values automatically.
https://neo4j.com/docs/cypher-manual/current/subqueries/collect/#collect-differentiation

Example dataset and queries:
```
CREATE (:project {id: '1'})-[:HAS]->(:Task {id: '1'})-[:ASSIGNED_TO]->(:Person {id:'1'})
CREATE (:project {id: '1'})-[:HAS]->(:Task {id: '2'})-[:ASSIGNED_TO]->(:Person {id:'2'})
CREATE (:project {id: '1'})-[:HAS]->(:Task {id: '3'})-[:ASSIGNED_TO]->(:Person {id:'3'})
CREATE (:project {id: '1'})-[:HAS]->(:Task {id: '4'})
CREATE (:project {id: '1'})-[:HAS]->(:Task {id: '5'})

//running the following query correctly fills out non-assigned tasks with null for a person:
MATCH (:project {id: '1'})--(t:Task)
OPTIONAL MATCH (t)-[:ASSIGNED_TO]-(p:Person)
RETURN t.id, p.id;

//running the collect function doesn't return the tasks with a null person:
MATCH (:project {id: '1'})--(t:Task)
OPTIONAL MATCH (t)-[:ASSIGNED_TO]-(p:Person)
RETURN collect(t.id, p.id);

//WORKAROUND: forcing the person id into a list includes the null values:
MATCH (:project {id: '1'})--(t:Task)
OPTIONAL MATCH (t)-[:ASSIGNED_TO]-(p:Person)
RETURN collect(t.id, [p.id]);
```
comments: A good way to start addressing this issue might be to review the `Aggregate` implementation in `operator.hpp` and `operator.cpp` to see how Memgraph handles null values. I suggest checking the `ProcessAll` and `ProcessOne` functions.
This is very important feature that doesn't seem to work. please fix it.

issueDTO.title: FEATURE REQUEST: Enhance Classification Prompt for Stricter DevRel Query Handling
issueDTO.description:
### Is your feature request related to a problem?

- [x] Yes, it is related to a problem

### Describe the feature you'd like

### 🌟 Feature Description

This feature focuses on a critical enhancement of the initial **Classification Prompt**. The goal is to refine the prompt's logic to be much stricter and more precise, ensuring that the DevRel agent is only triggered for queries that are explicitly its responsibility. This involves improving the instructions the LLM uses to decide whether a message requires agent intervention.

Additionally, this task includes a secondary objective to review all other existing prompts (`agent_prompt`, `summarization_prompt`, etc.) for clarity, efficiency, and alignment with the latest system architecture.

### 🔍 Problem Statement

Currently, the classification prompt may be too broad, leading to the DevRel agent responding to general conversations or messages where it's not needed. This can create several issues:

1.  **Unnecessary Invocations**: The agent wastes resources processing irrelevant messages.
2.  **User Annoyance**: An AI assistant that injects itself into every conversation can be perceived as intrusive or unhelpful.
3.  **Lack of Precision**: The agent may misinterpret context and provide answers when it should remain silent, degrading the quality of the user experience.

The core problem is a lack of **strict activation boundaries** for the agent.

### 🎯 Expected Outcome

1.  **Modified Classification Prompt**: The `Classification Prompt` will be rewritten to include new, strict rules. The agent should **only** be activated if one of the following conditions is met:
      * The user **explicitly tags or mentions** the DevRel AI bot (e.g., `@Devr.AI, can you help?`).
      * The user's query is a direct question about the project, community, contribution process, or a technical issue clearly related to the repository (e.g., "How do I set up the development environment?", "I'm getting a build error.").
      * The prompt will explicitly instruct the model to **ignore** general chatter, greetings, and conversations between other users unless the bot is tagged.
2.  **Reduced False Positives**: After implementation, there should be a measurable decrease in the number of times the agent responds to irrelevant conversations.
3.  **Improved Prompt Suite**: A brief review of all other system prompts will be conducted, with minor enhancements made for clarity and conciseness.

### Record

- [x] I agree to follow this project's Code of Conduct
- [ ] I want to work on implementing this feature
comments: @smokeyScraper would like to try this out. Can u assign this to me so that I can start working on it?
yep @HarK-github, you can give it a try.

Hey @smokeyScraper 👋

I'd love to work on this issue. I???ve already contributed the `thinking_node` to improve query understanding, and I???d like to now focus on refining the classification logic for smarter agent activation.

### 🔧 My plan:
- Rework the `classification_prompt.txt` to include stricter conditions ??? such as only triggering on direct bot mentions or clearly scoped technical questions.
- Explicitly instruct the model to ignore greetings, general chatter, or unrelated discussions.
- Test with real examples to reduce false positives and ensure clean triggering.
- As a bonus, I???ll also review the other prompt files (e.g., `agent_prompt`, `summarization_prompt`) for clarity and alignment with the current flow.

Let me know if this direction works for you ??? and please assign me if it???s good to proceed! 🚀

issueDTO.title: Automatically Resize Large Images Before Upload
issueDTO.description:
As a Second Life resident, I want the viewer to automatically downscale images larger than 2048??2048, So that I can easily upload high-resolution images (like 4K or 5K) without needing to preprocess them manually. Description Currently, the viewer displays an error when attempting to upload images larger than 2048??2048 pixels. However, Second Life only supports a maximum texture resolution of 1024??1024. This creates unnecessary friction for users who commonly work with high-resolution images, particularly on modern displays. ## Acceptance Criteria - Images larger than 2048??2048 are automatically downscaled by the viewer before upload. - The viewer prompts the user or displays a notification when an image is being downscaled. - Possibly a note on the image upload preview - Downscaled images must respect SL???s maximum image resolution of 2048??2048. - The upload process remains consistent with current pricing and compression settings. - Edge cases like non-square images and images with alpha channels are handled appropriately. - Both bulk and single-image upload paths updated
## Screenshots _The current viewer image uploader is unable to handle images larger than 2048x2048._ ## Reward Please follow our [reward guidelines](https://github.com/secondlife/.github/blob/main/REWARDS.md) if you would like to be compensated for completing this task.

issueDTO.title: Expression / Formula editor doesn't respect units.
issueDTO.description:
### Is there an existing issue for this?

- [X] I have searched the existing issues

### Problem description

If you go into a parameter box and click the formula / expression icon in the upper right hand corner and type in a number without a unit (such as in or " for example), it returns back with the proper number in the main parameter box, however, when you okay out, it converts the number to metric.  If you simply type in the number in the normal parameter box without going into the expression / formula editor, it respects the default units as expected.  This looks to affect multiple workbenches including sketcher and CAM.

OS: Debian GNU/Linux 12 (bookworm) (GNOME/gnome)
Word size of FreeCAD: 64-bit
Version: 1.0.0RC2.38806 (Git) AppImage

issueDTO.title: Refactor codebase to use value parameters instead of pointers where appropriate
issueDTO.description:
Many methods in the codebase, such as:

```go

func (s *RepositoriesService) CreateRelease(ctx context.Context, owner, repo string, release *RepositoryRelease) (*RepositoryRelease, *Response, error)
```

use pointer parameters (e.g. `*RepositoryRelease`) even when the function doesn't mutate the input. This appears to be a result of convention or copy-paste, not a performance-driven choice.

For instance, in `CreateRelease`, the `RepositoryRelease` struct is relatively large (~15+ fields), but most of its fields are pointers themselves. As such, passing it by value would have negligible performance impact in typical API usage. Moreover, value semantics would improve clarity, especially for required arguments that aren't modified.

To improve API design consistency and safety, we should:

- Audit method signatures that accept pointer structs as input
- Change them to accept values when:

  - The input is required (not optional)

  - The function does not modify the input

- Optionally introduce dedicated input structs for specific operations (e.g. `CreateRepositoryRelease` with only the fields needed for creation)

Note: This would be a breaking change and should be handled carefully, possibly across multiple PRs.

_Originally posted by @gmlewis in https://github.com/google/go-github/pull/3636#discussion_r2228429223_

Ideally, we prefer to assign owners to issues so that work does not get accidentally duplicated.

As for separating it into multiple PRs, we prefer to keep PRs on the smaller side when possible to make them easier to review and to understand. Since this repo is divided into multiple "Service" areas, it might make sense to make a separate PR for each different GitHub service.

I'll assign the issue to you, @rupokghosh, since it sounds like you are interested in working on this.  Thank you!

issueDTO.title: opt: add rule to simplify const comparison with ANY values
issueDTO.description:
Given a constant value compared using the `ANY` or `SOME` operators, we should be able to check for constants in the right hand side that can be used to simplify the comparison to `True`. For example, the expression: `0.1 < ANY (c0, 0.4)` could be simplified since `0.1 < 0.4`.

Jira issue: CRDB-42979
comments: Hi @DrewKimball, I would like to work on this issue. Can you assign it to me?

Hi @zenc0derr, thanks for picking this one up! Feel free to ask general questions about contributing on our [community slack](https://cockroachdb.slack.com/ssb/redirect). You can ask questions to do with this issue specifically here.
Hi @zenc0derr, do you think you'll be able to work on this soon? If not, we can unassign you, and give other contributors a chance to work on it.
Hi @DrewKimball, Apologies for the delay. Was not well for few weeks. Working on it now. Thanks
@DrewKimball, could you provide some guidance on where to start with this issue?
Hi @DrewKimball, I'm interested in tackling this issue. Would it be possible for you to assign me?
@ahuangg done! Feel free to give it a shot!

@mgartner 
Before I proceed with the implementation, I want to confirm my approach. It seems the goal of this optimization is to simplify the comparisons involving ANY or SOME operators when the left hand is constant and the right side contains a constant that can evaluate the operation to be True.

To achieve this, I was considering adding a function called FoldAnyWithConst in [fold_constants.opt](https://github.com/ahuangg/cockroach/blob/master/pkg/sql/opt/norm/rules/fold_constants.opt) 
```
# FoldAnyWithConst simplifies a scalar ANY operation when the left side is constant
# and the right side contains a constant that can determine the result, like this:
# 0.1 < ANY (c0, 0.4) can be simplified since 0.1 < 0.4 is True
[FoldAnyWithConst, Normalize]
(AnyScalar
    $left:* & (IsConstValueOrGroupOfConstValues $left)
    $right:* &
    (Let
        ($result $ok):(FoldAnyWithConst (OpName) $left $right) $ok
    )
)
=>
$result
```
then doing the actual implementation of the function in [fold_constants_funcs.go](https://github.com/ahuangg/cockroach/blob/master/pkg/sql/opt/norm/fold_constants_funcs.go) in a similar fashion to how the other functions are implemented in the file. 

Please let me know what you think, feedback is appreciated.

That sounds like the correct approach to me.

One thing we'll have to be mindful about is `NULL` values. We should be find as long as we only fold to `true`, and never `false`.

```sql
SELECT 1 < ANY (2, NULL), 1 < ANY(0, NULL);
--   ?column? | ?column?
-- -----------+-----------
--      t     |   NULL
-- (1 row)
```

Seeing as this issue has been inactive for a month - can this be assigned to me?

@DrewKimball @mgartner

Hi @DrewKimball and @rytaft,

I'd like to work on this issue. I noticed it was last assigned about three months ago with no recent activity. Would it be possible to assign it to me so I can start working on it?

Thanks!
Sounds like @ahuangg made some progress on this issue. Are you still working on it, @ahuangg? If not, I'll assign to @sambhavKhanna.
Hello @ahuangg & @rytaft ! Just checking in to see if this issue is still open???happy to pick it up. I???ve already prepared a changeset and can start working on it as soon as I get the green light.
Hi @YRathod -- please go for it! I'll assign you.

issueDTO.title: Bug: [CLI] Iteration limit enforced at default despite config.toml setting max_iterations=1000
issueDTO.description:
## Bug Description

When running OpenHands from CLI with a custom `config.toml` that sets `max_iterations = 1000`, the system still stops execution at 500 iterations (the default limit) with an iteration limit error.

## Environment
- **Installation**: Development version installed with `pip install openhands -e .`
- **Command**: `openhands -n vscode-runtime` (run from project directory)
- **Config**: Custom `config.toml` with `max_iterations = 1000`
- **Verification**: Other config options from the same file are being respected

## Expected Behavior
The system should respect the `max_iterations = 1000` setting from `config.toml` and allow up to 1000 iterations before stopping.

## Actual Behavior
The system stops at 500 iterations with an iteration limit error, ignoring the custom configuration.

## Steps to Reproduce
1. Create/modify `config.toml` with `max_iterations = 1000`
2. Install development version: `pip install openhands -e .`
3. Run: `openhands -n vscode-runtime`
4. Observe that execution stops at 500 iterations despite config setting

## Additional Context
- The config file is definitely being read (other settings are applied)
- This affects workflows where longer sessions are needed

---
*Reported by: OpenHands-Claude (AI Assistant)*

issueDTO.title: [CLI] Advanced settings modification requires replacing all settings one-by-one
issueDTO.description:
## Problem
When modifying advanced settings in the CLI, users cannot change individual settings. Instead, they must replace all settings one-by-one, even if they only want to change a single value.

## Current Behavior
- `/settings` ??? Advanced ??? User must input all settings again
- Cannot selectively modify just one setting (e.g., only the API key)
- Forces users to re-enter all configuration values

## Expected Behavior
- Allow selective modification of individual settings
- Show current values and allow users to keep existing values
- Provide options like "Keep current value" or show defaults

## User Experience Impact
- Frustrating when only wanting to change one setting
- Risk of introducing errors when re-entering all values
- Time-consuming for users with complex configurations

## Technical Context
The issue is in the settings modification flow in `openhands/cli/settings.py`, specifically in the `modify_llm_settings_advanced()` function.

## Proposed Solutions
1. **Interactive setting selection**: Allow users to choose which settings to modify
2. **Current value display**: Show existing values and allow keeping them
3. **Incremental updates**: Only prompt for settings the user wants to change

## Related Files
- `openhands/cli/settings.py` (modify_llm_settings_advanced function)
- `openhands/cli/commands.py` (handle_settings_command function)

issueDTO.title: [CLI] Settings changes require restart even when no session is active
issueDTO.description:
## Problem
Settings changes require a restart to take effect, even when no session has been started yet. This creates unnecessary friction in the setup process.

## Current Behavior
- User modifies settings via `/settings`
- CLI shows "They will take effect after restart"
- Restart is required even if no agent session is running

## Expected Behavior
- Settings should take effect immediately when no session is active
- Only require restart when an active session would be affected
- Provide immediate feedback when settings are successfully applied

## User Experience Impact
- Adds unnecessary steps to initial setup
- Confusing when no session is running
- Breaks the flow of configuration

## Technical Context
The settings are loaded at startup in `main_with_loop()` and not reloaded during runtime. The configuration could be reloaded when no session is active.

## Proposed Solution
1. **Immediate application**: Apply settings immediately when no session is running
2. **Smart restart detection**: Only require restart when an active session exists
3. **Clear messaging**: Different messages based on whether restart is actually needed

## Related Files
- `openhands/cli/main.py` (settings loading in main_with_loop)
- `openhands/cli/settings.py` (save_settings_confirmation function)
- `openhands/storage/settings/file_settings_store.py`

issueDTO.title: [CLI] Diffs should display side-by-side on wider displays for better space usage
issueDTO.description:
## Problem
File diffs are currently displayed in unified format, which doesn't make optimal use of screen space on wider displays. Side-by-side diffs would be more readable and efficient.

## Current Behavior
- All diffs shown in unified format (+ and - lines)
- Doesn't utilize available horizontal space on wide terminals
- Can be harder to compare changes visually

## Expected Behavior
- Detect terminal width and use side-by-side diff when space allows
- Fall back to unified diff on narrow terminals
- Better visual comparison of before/after states

## User Experience Impact
- **Readability**: Side-by-side is often easier to understand
- **Space efficiency**: Better use of wide terminal windows
- **Visual clarity**: Clearer separation of old vs new content

## Proposed Solution
1. **Terminal width detection**: Check available columns
2. **Adaptive display**: Use side-by-side when width > threshold (e.g., 120 columns)
3. **Fallback**: Keep unified diff for narrow terminals

Example side-by-side format:
```
File Edit
?????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????
??? Before                    ??? After                           ???
??? ??????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????? ???
??? def old_function():       ??? def new_function():             ???
???     return "old"          ???     return "new"                ???
???                           ???     # Added comment             ???
?????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????
```

## Technical Context
The change would be in `display_file_edit()` function in `openhands/cli/tui.py`, utilizing the `CustomDiffLexer` and potentially extending it.

## Related Files
- `openhands/cli/tui.py` (display_file_edit function, CustomDiffLexer class)
- `openhands/events/observation.py` (FileEditObservation.visualize_diff method)

issueDTO.title: [Feature] healthcheck command
issueDTO.description:
### Use case

Docker HEALTHCHECK

### Description

Headscale does not come with a (easy) way of checking health using only the CLI. This is especially painful when running Headscale inside a docker container

### Contribution

- [X] I can write the design doc for this feature
- [X] I can contribute this feature

### How can it be implemented?

Should be pretty simple as it could tie into the already existing `/health` endpoint
comments: Can't you just use curl?

> Can't you just use curl?

@kradalby Unfortunately not an option for some Environments. For example: inside the provided distroless Docker container (non debug) there is no curl nor shell.

fair enough, I wont prioritise this but sounds like a good issue for someone who wants to help out.

If this is implemented, it needs to be added to the API, and if we do that, we should probably remove the old endpoint and only use the API one for other uses.

Alternatively, the CLI can not use the gRPC API at all and just call the endpoint that currently exists. The downside of that is that you dont get to verify that the gRPC stack works, so I would prefer the first option.

As a workaround for end-users, bash at least is included in `docker.io/headscale/headscale:0.22.3`. This enables using `/dev/tcp` to check if the API port is open via something like (assuming you're using the default API port): `bash -c 'cat < /dev/null > /dev/tcp/localhost/8080'`. See https://medium.com/@stefanos.kalandaridis/bash-ing-your-network-f7069ab7c5f4 for a decent primer on how it works.

This is among the weakest of healthcheck options in that it simply verifies that SOMETHING is able to accept a tcp connection on the API port. It says nothing about the health of the gRPC stack or any in-memory or on-disk state. It also says nothing about DERP, which could maybe be interrogated via `/dev/udp` but doing so requires knowing a valid message to send that will elicit a response and not leak resources along the way. I haven't configured a derp check myself.

This isn't a high-quality replacement for the stronger checks proposed in other comments... but it's start that allows monitoring frameworks to check that the API is at least healthy enough to complete a 3-way TCP handshake in image-flavors that have bash available.

> This enables using /dev/tcp to check if the API port is open via something like (assuming you're using the default API port): `bash -c 'cat < /dev/null > /dev/tcp/localhost/8080'`

No **bash** nor **sh** in `headscale/headscale:v0.25`

What I saw in other go programs is a health check made in main of the go program.
So you can make use of http client.

Hey all. Been using headscale for a while, love it, and wanted to start getting into your codebase further and take this one first, if possible. I have some ideas and I think this will be handy to have.
This issue is stale because it has been open for 90 days with no activity.

issueDTO.title: [FR]: New Evaluaton Metric "Trajectory Accuracy"
issueDTO.description:
### Proposal summary

We like to extend the existing evaluation metrics to include a new metric called "Trajectory Accuracy". Esentially we are evaluating ReAct style agents by reasoning about the sequence of actions taken and their outcomes. Based on the paper ???ReAct: Synergizing Reasoning and Acting in Language Models??? https://arxiv.org/abs/2210.03629. You can also see the Langchain implementation here:
- https://python.langchain.com/api_reference/langchain/evaluation/langchain.evaluation.agents.trajectory_eval_chain.TrajectoryEvalChain.html
- https://github.com/langchain-ai/agentevals/tree/main/python/agentevals/trajectory

Example of an existing judge metric (Hallucination) is defined here:
- Docs: https://www.comet.com/docs/opik/evaluation/metrics/hallucination
- Docs Code: https://github.com/comet-ml/opik/blob/main/apps/opik-documentation/documentation/fern/docs/evaluation/metrics/hallucination.mdx
- Python SDK: https://github.com/comet-ml/opik/tree/main/sdks/python/src/opik/evaluation/metrics/llm_judges/hallucination
- Python Examples: https://github.com/comet-ml/opik/blob/main/sdks/python/examples/metrics.py
- Frontend: https://github.com/comet-ml/opik/blob/main/apps/opik-frontend/src/constants/llm.ts

Ideally this is implemented as an LLM-as-a-judge. Expectation is the new judge is added to the frontend for using LLM-as-a-judge from the UI (Online Evaluation tab) as well as in the Python SDK. The appropriate docs needs to be updated and a video attached of the metric working.

Return should be float (0-1), and if its using LLM as a eval then should also contain a "reason/explanation"

### Motivation

I would like to see more robust set of metrics and evaluations based on recent research.

issueDTO.title: Update Python libraries and tests from Python 3.13
issueDTO.description:
Though it will be sometimes blocked by rust side issues, don't worry!
Please just create PR about the broken test and and create issues related to the new bugs.

If you are new to updating cpython libraries, this guide will be useful:
https://github.com/RustPython/RustPython/wiki/How-to-update-test-files

When updating module Lib/X, please don't forget to also update Lib/test/test_X

A few libraries doesn't need to be updated because CPython also kept it same as previous version. In that case, please leave a comment to let us mark it as done. Thank you!

Tips
- To get specific version of CPython source code, e.g. try `git checkout v3.13.1` from CPython repository.
- Please check #4064 for example. Not the entire changes but the each commits. One of the middle size example is https://github.com/RustPython/RustPython/commit/17e12dea1ec11b871a9e5d3a4a26e2f9ad83fde2 . Sometimes it can be really simple like https://github.com/RustPython/RustPython/pull/4064/commits/9571a68c01284191d4b18229694c303dad8992ff
- Please create one PR for one library+test pair whenever possible. Once you stuck by dependencies, go to one of the dependency first and finish it before restarting the stuck one unless they become simpler to be updated at the same time. Normally adding more libraries make passing tests (a lot) harder.
- To run tests, try `cargo run --features ssl -- -m test -v <test_name>`. e.g. If you changed `test_unicode.py`, `cargo run --features ssl -- -m test -v test_unicode`
  - If it runs too slow, try to add `--release` like `cargo run --release --features ssl -- -m test -v test_unicode`

Python 3.13 added the following test 
```python
with self.assertWarns(DeprecationWarning):
            # We need to put the bool in a variable, because the constant
            # ~False is evaluated at compile time due to constant folding;
            # consequently the DeprecationWarning would be issued during
            # module loading and not during test execution.
            false = False
            self.assertEqual(~false, -1)
```
AFAICT, this is deceptively a big change to how its implemented now. It seems to me that bools are just ints in RustPython? The call to `~false` here delegates to PyInt::invert.

issueDTO.title: FeatureHasher and HashingVectorizer does not expose requires_fit=False tag
issueDTO.description:
While `FeatureHasher` and `HashingVectorizer` are stateless estimator (at least in their docstrings), they do not expose the `requires_fit` tag to `False` as other stateless estimator.

@adrinjalali Do you recall when changing the tags if there was a particular reason for those estimator to not behave the same way than others?
comments:
My PR didn't change a tag in that regard: 

https://github.com/scikit-learn/scikit-learn/pull/29677/files#diff-2ce614636a32fc7ddace8d5f36e320e0b348012dff967ad17c7fed8ea40b5723R196

Note that `requires_fit` is tricky if the estimator does input / feature name / feature count validation.
/take
@glemaitre what condition would be require to set `requires_fit` tag to be False or is that the default behaviour?

_Hi! I'm interested in working on this issue as my first contribution._

I **understand that `FeatureHasher` and `HashingVectorizer` are stateless estimators and should have the `requires_fit = False` tag set, just like other stateless estimators.**

I'd love to help fix this. Could you please **assign** this issue to me?

Thanks!
/take
We don't assign issues to anybody, and we also don't have a `/take` bot anymore. If you think you can handle the issue, please write how you think you can solve it, and then open a pull request.

@adrinjalali Thank you for the clarification. I was reading through the online web documentation so I thought it was still in place. I mainly am new to open-source and want to find a way to contribute. 

Do you think it would be worth while if I opened an issue to update the online documentation to reflect that a bot is no longer used (Unless it states this that I didnt see)?

Hi, I'd like to work on this issue.

My plan is to:
- Override the _get_tags() method in both FeatureHasher and HashingVectorizer to explicitly return "requires_fit": False.
- This will ensure the tag correctly reflects their stateless behavior, as neither class requires fitting before transforming.
- I'll also add unit tests to verify that this tag is correctly set.

I'll submit a PR shortly. Let me know if you have any suggestions or concerns. Thanks!

Hello maintainers, I am new to OSS, but I used to use scikit-learn for my classes projects at OSU. Could you please let me know if I can work on this issue? Thank you and looking forward to hearing from you soon.

summary.validationOrRequirement: The `requires_fit` tag should be set to `False` for stateless estimators like `FeatureHasher` and `HashingVectorizer`.
summary.attemptedFixes: The contributor plans to override the `_get_tags()` method in both classes to explicitly return `requires_fit=False` and add unit tests to verify the tag.
summary.otherNotes: The issue is about exposing the `requires_fit=False` tag for `FeatureHasher` and `HashingVectorizer` as they are stateless estimators.

issueDTO.title: Feature: Require or recommend the `timeout-minutes` property for all jobs
issueDTO.description:
### Pre-submission checks

- [x] I am **not** reporting a bug (crash, false positive/negative, etc). These must be filed via the bug report template.
- [x] I have looked through the open issues for a duplicate request.

### What's the problem this feature will solve?

The `timeout-minutes` property can be used to prevent run-away jobs from consuming all your allowed GitHub Actions runner minutes. [The default value is 360 minutes](https://docs.github.com/en/actions/reference/workflow-syntax-for-github-actions#jobsjob_idtimeout-minutes) (6 hours).

Examples include scripts that accidentally hang or go into a loop, package managers which slow to a crawl when the registry is responding slowly, compilers that get stuck, or really anything else that can unexpectedly slow but not be constrained by its own timeout.

I use this property on all jobs in all my workflows.

### Describe the solution you'd like

I would like Zizmor to enforce or recommend the use of a `timeout-minutes` property on all jobs. This property is not strictly related to security, but I think it's such a useful configuration that it could be part of the "pedantic" or "auditor" persona.

At a stretch, you could suggest that a vulnerability in a workflow could allow an attacker to consume all your GitHub Actions minutes, and this would protect against that, but honestly it's more likely that `npm install` hangs and eats all your allowance.

### Additional context

Jobs which call a reusable workflow (with `uses`) do not support `timeout-minutes`. The property needs to be defined in the jobs within the reusable workflow that it calls.
comments:
Thanks @johnbillion! Yeah, I agree this would be good as a "pedantic" finding. 

(I agree with your comments about security relevance -- this is funny in that it cuts both ways, i.e. an attacker could waste resources without `timeout-minutes`, *or* they could induce an availability risk with `timeout-minutes`. Which one is more important probably ends up being context- and trigger-sensitive.)

Hey @woodruffw , @johnbillion,
I'd like to work on this issue. 
I'm relatively new to contributing to Python projects but have experience with CI/CD workflows and GitHub Actions. 
Could you point me to any existing checks that would be good examples to follow for implementing this feature?

Hi @EmmanuelBerkowicz, thanks for offering your time.

This is a Rust project, not a Python project, just so you know 😉 

> Could you point me to any existing checks that would be good examples to follow for implementing this feature?

Any of the pre-existing audits that use `audit_normal_job` would probably be a pretty good reference point -- see `UnpinnedImages` for example:

https://github.com/zizmorcore/zizmor/blob/22958cba7586b81790213b908f23bf86f092d834/crates/zizmor/src/audit/unpinned_images.rs#L49

(This audit _should_ be simpler than most -- it should be mostly a matter of checking `timeout_minutes` on each job and step, and raising a finding if any is missing or if the step(s) aren't transitively covered by the job.)

The docs here should also help a bit, although they're also a bit stale: https://docs.zizmor.sh/development/#adding-or-modifying-an-audit
Yeah, that's no problem at all. Let me know if you have any questions about the codebase!

Hey @woodruffw ,
Sorry for getting onto this so late. Work and Study pilled on me together.
I'm setting this up, but I can't install homebrew because I am on windows.
Do you know of a workaround for this?
Thanks!

No problem.

issueDTO.title: Improve viewer UX by moving stats near cursor
issueDTO.description: ### Problem Viewers (and new players) struggle to correlate on-map actions with context info shown in the top-right corner (`player-info-overlay`). Especially as a viewer it's difficult to keep track of where the mouse is and the top right overlay info to understand what its hovering. https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/db5749e1-7e85-4d00-ae40-7d12272d5a71 ### Proposed Solution Mirror or relocate the contents of `player-info-overlay` next to the mouse position. https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/733076ec-d02d-4816-8110-3ee11eb01199 A simple dynamic HUD under the cursor can: - Instantly show stats using clear visual emojis - Visually link context data to the cursor position - Improve UX with a simple UI change ### Try it now If any youtuber (plis Ultimus_Rex) want to try it now, here is the user script I did for the demo. Just copy and paste it to the dev tools (F12) at any point while playing to get the HUD. https://gist.github.com/SrZorro/0d77e96d60faa5e5654da26e497e258f ### Benefits - Greatly improves accessibility and clarity in videos and streams - Helps players make faster decisions during gameplay

issueDTO.title: Render code examples automatically with sphinx_gallery
issueDTO.description:
Currently our non-notebook examples are manually included in the examples webpage via custom `.rst` files in `tutorial/source/`.  As the number of examples increases, it would be better to follow [NumPyro's approach](http://pyro.ai/numpyro/examples/) and generate HTML pages automatically with [`sphinx_gallery`](https://sphinx-gallery.github.io/stable/index.html).  This would make examples easier to find and read, improve the design of the tutorial page, and declutter our tutorial folder on GitHub.  Many of the examples also contain extensive docstrings and comments that `sphinx_gallery` could automatically render in HTML.

More ambitiously, we might even aim to use `sphinx_gallery` to include tutorials in ReadTheDocs, simplifying our release process and removing the lag between new tutorials being added on GitHub and becoming visible on the examples web page.
comments:
> More ambitiously, we might even aim to use sphinx_gallery to include tutorials in ReadTheDocs, simplifying our release process and removing the lag between new tutorials being added on GitHub and becoming visible on the examples web page.

This is what I wanted for a long time!
This worked really well in NumPyro, so hopefully we can just copy the `sphinx_gallery` boilerplate from there and set up similar redirects to keep links alive.

As motivation, I forgot to manually update tutorials during Pyro's 1.5.1 release, so users like @lucapinello experienced errors. Indeed it would be nice to automate this and eliminate possibility of human error.
Hello! Is this issue available to work on? If so, I would like to claim it! I plan to have a pull request submitted in two weeks.
@gioviebell go ahead! but you may want to describe your plan of action before doing too much work and submitting a PR

issueDTO.title: Implement `install_*` macro from boulder
issueDTO.description:
File permission on Linux is confusing for new packager. Simplifying the install step by using macro instead of number would make the process easier. We already have the example from [`boulder`](https://github.com/AerynOS/os-tools/blob/3f1d23e1977dad91569af79ee006b196b589abf9/boulder/data/macros/actions/misc.yaml#L14C3-L38). 

The related repo wide transition can be discussed after work on this is underway, but I have notes from my conversation with @ermo :

> 07:44 PM
> 
> current solus:
> 
> install -Dm0755 something tosomehwere/
> 
> proposed solus:
> 
> %install_exe something tosomewhere/
> 
> (edited)
> 07:45 PM
> in this case, you can programmatically replace the first install -Dm0755 invocation with %install_exe, and the command will be idempotent, so you won't need to bump the recipe. (edited)
> hence "No Functional Change", as the recipe will be built with the macros the next time it's bumped.
> 07:46 PM
> Then, the next time it's bumped and people try to build it, you will discover if the replace worked as you expected.
> Rather than having to manually trawl through all of the replaces and check if they build now
> hence "amortising".
> It's much cheaper for solus to do it this way in terms of human attention hours here and now (edited)
> 07:49 PM
> the regexp would look something like this sed -E -e 's|\(^[[:blank:]]*\)install \-Dm0755|\1%install_exe|g'
> Fair enough if you think I'm talking rubbish. It's just how I'd do it, after I'd tested that all the new %install_* macros work on recipes where it matters and then I'd auto-replace in all other recipes and punt the checking of those to when they need a bump anyway. (edited)
> 07:51 PM
> (I am unsure if the - needs \ style escapes when using posix regexps)
> 07:53 PM
> Ok, I understand now what you meant.
> If we can do it programatically, that would he awesome.
> 07:55 PM
> find -name package.yml -exec <the sed expression from above, but add -i for "replace-in-place"> '{}' \; (edited)
> 07:55 PM
> I did think of doing the repo wide transition would be a good old fashioned cleanup crew task.
> 07:55 PM
> it's pretty simple to do.
> The cleanup crew can still do it
> but if you test that all the replaces work, you're almost there.
> HTH
> 07:57 PM
> so you'd do tests on leaf-packages with each kind of expression
> (i.e. bump, test macros, commit)
> Then do a full-repo [NFC] replace.
> because you've just tested that the regexps and the outcomes are good.
> simple enough in theory.
> Then you only need to hand-edit the recipes that are being "difficult"
> 07:59 PM
> We are kinda getting ahead here. The macro is not in Solus yet.
> I like the macro, because i think new packager can understand the term easier compared to understanding nix file permission.
> (I know this because I was confused about it and still is)
> 08:05 PM
> Now you know why I created it and insisted on using it 😉 (edited)
> 08:05 PM
> The method you proposed sounds like good one. I will keep all that in mind (Heck I will save it one notes too👍???)
> 08:05 PM
> I know. I am showing you the cost of doing it if you do it the smart way =)
> 
> New Messages
> 08:06 PM
> (apologies for sounding like an intolerable smart-alec)
> 
???

issueDTO.title: [MCP] Hunter
issueDTO.description:
## 🧩 Product Overview

Hunter helps you find, verify, and manage professional email addresses at scale.  
This integration enables AI agents and workflows to automate email discovery, validation, lead tracking, and campaign outreach.

---

## ?????? Important Note for Contributors

This feature must be submitted as a [Piece](https://www.activepieces.com/docs/developers/building-pieces/piece-definition) following the Activepieces architecture. Submissions not following this format will not be accepted. Please review the [Piece Development Guidelines](https://www.activepieces.com/docs/developers/building-pieces/overview) before development.

**Contributors based in India: please check your eligibility for receiving payments through your Stripe account before submitting, as this may affect your ability to get paid.**

---

## 🚨 Triggers

| **Trigger**                | **Use Case** |
|---------------------------|--------------|
| **New Lead**              | Fires when a new lead is created. |


---

## 🛠??? Write Actions

| **Action Item**              | **Use Case** |
|------------------------------|--------------|
| **Add Recipients**           | Add one or multiple recipients to a campaign.|
| **Count Emails**             | Returns the number of email addresses found for a domain or company. Useful before running full searches.|
| **Create a Lead**            | Create and store a lead record.  |
| **Delete a Lead**            | Delete a specific lead record by ID.  |
| **Find an Email**            | Retrieve/propose the most likely email for a person at a domain.  |
| **Get a Lead**               | Retrieve details of a specific lead.|
| **Update a Lead**            | Modify existing lead data.} |
| **Verify an Email**          | Check email deliverability and validation status. |

Unknown, but definitely version 2.x.x

### What happened?

Last week Dags began erroring with ""Repeated values for field enableComponents may not be None"" when they had been working fine prior.  I have no idea why all of a sudden this issue occurred and have checked whether enableComponents is set in LoggingConfig and monitoringConfig - which they are. These pods worked last week with no changes and all of a sudden they do not.
